PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, will be absent from the chamber during Question Time today. As I think he mentioned yesterday, he is attending a memorial service in Sydney for the late John Maddison. He will be returning to the Senate later this morning. Therefore, questions which ordinarily would have been addressed to him should be addressed to me on this occasion.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, may also concern the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I join Senator Primmer and others in referring to the abnormal delay in Australia selecting Uruguayan immigrants from a refugee camp in Brazil. I ask: Will the Minister inquire of both departments how long it will take to finalise the selection, which was originally undertaken under the humanitarian program? The Uruguayan community in Sydney and Melbourne is rather impatient that the ultimate selection should take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the matter to the two Ministers concerned. Senator Mulvihill may have an opportunity to pursue the matter at the Senate Estimates committee hearings.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education, refers to the notice given by the Minister yesterday of the introduction in the Senate of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982, which deals with the student loans scheme. I ask: What progress has been made in final negotiations with the banks for the detailed arrangements under the scheme? Guidelines were announced in the Budget context and have been welcomed by many students as providing a resource additional to those provided under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and post-graduate awards. They have real expectations concerning the final details. When will the details be prepared and what progress has been made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave notice that this morning I would be introducing in the Senate a Bill to guarantee loans made to students. The only legislation required to put a student loans scheme in place is a Bill to provide the appropriate guarantees in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act. Therefore, it is not necessary to have all of the detailed arrangements with the banks complete at this time. Negotiations with the Commonwealth Bank, the trading banks and the Australian Bankers Association are continuing. They are being conducted by my colleague the Treasurer. Senator Messner, as Minister Assisting the Treasurer, may be undertaking some of that work on his behalf. There is no legislative requirement for that part of the arrangement, so we are not treating it with the same urgency; but because a loan guarantee Bill is needed it will be introduced today.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the Government, in announcing the proposed student loans scheme , advised that it would provide for an interest rate that would be 5 per cent below the current overdraft interest rate; that is, students would be able to get a concessional rate of interest 5 per cent below the ruling overdraft rate. That is an extremely generous provision for students who wish to take out loans. In addition, the scheme would provide for a two-year holiday, as it were, after graduation before repayments would need to commence. These provisions give considerable assistance to those who had worried that the scheme might have conditions or provisions which were unacceptable. I think people are quite reassured by what is in the proposed scheme and, as I say, I will be introducing the Bill today and I hope that the Senate will deal with it in the next week or couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate seen statements published this morning by the President of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party, Mr Ian Warner? Does Mr Warner say that both the Party President, Dr Forbes, and the Prime Minister have misrepresented the terms of the debate about retrospective tax legislation at the Liberal Party national executive meeting two weeks ago? Can the Minister tell the Senate whether, as Mr Warner suggests, the Prime Minister made concessions to those members of the Liberal Party who oppose retrospective legislation? If Mr Warner is correct, will the Minister now tell the Senate and the Australian taxpayers generally what these concessions were?
—Senator Button asked me whether I had seen a statement by Mr Warner today. I have not seen a statement by him today, although I think I answered a question yesterday about a comment he made.
—Press reports on the statement today.

—It may be the same statement that was reported in the Australian Financial Review yesterday. All that I am aware of in relation to what Mr Warner said is what I read in the Australian Financial Review yesterday. I gather from what Senator Button said that it is much the same sort of statement that is reported today. I was not present at the meeting and I cannot personally comment on what transpired there; but the President of the Liberal Party, Dr Forbes, made a statement clearly indicating the support of the federal executive at that meeting for the Government's proposed legislation to recover from vendor shareholders company tax that has been evaded through the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I understand that the other State presidents have all indicated that the executive has supported that legislation. I cannot comment further on Mr Warner's views other than simply to refer to what has been said by the Prime Minister and by Dr Forbes. I do not know whether other presidents have yet publicly made statements of support for what Dr Forbes has said but certainly the Government, with the support of the federal executive of the Liberal Party, is pressing ahead with this most important legislation, to which it gives the utmost priority. It is being drafted. Of course it is technical legislation and has to be carefully drafted, and a little time is necessary to do that. A special group of Ministers, which I am chairing in the absence of the Treasurer, has already been working on the legislation. Certainly it is our intention at this stage that that legislation should be introduced into this Parliament during the current sitting period-that is, before we rise for the Commonwealth Games. I trust that the legislation will get the full support of the Parliament. I want to emphasise that this was a major initiative of the Government taken before the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and before the Opposition started to make a song and dance about this subject.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, who is the Minister in charge of the Australian Federal Police. It relates to a leaflet headed 'Aboriginal Fighting Front, 26th of January Action Commando' and said to be circulating in Sydney, and I understand more recently also in Melbourne, which was placed in my hands by a constituent in Sydney. I provided the Minister with a copy of this leaflet yesterday since he obviously would have to be aware of its contents to answer my question. In order to make it intelligible to honourable senators, Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate most of the text in Hansard, but not that section purporting to be a recipe for a self-igniting napalm bomb.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ABORIGINAL FIGHTING FRONT
26th of January Action Commando
July 1982

On the 26th of January 1788 Captain Arthur Phillip claimed Australia for the white man and fired the first shot in a war which will never end until the white man is hurled back into the sea from which he came.
Comrades, we should rid our ranks of all impotent thinking. All views that overestimate the strength of the enemy and underestimate the strength of the people are wrong!!
For too long have the multi-national capitalist conglomerates grown rich on the harvest of our tribal lands.
Directors and board members grow fat on the riches of sacred lands that have been raped for their mineral wealth.
Force is the only means the leaders of the giant corporations understand. We must fight them with their own weapons.
We cannot rely on the word of the white man. Our brothers in Tasmania believed in his friendship, now they are DEAD!!!
We must hit the white man where it hurts him, in his pocket. We must use every means within our power, including direct action, to cause his downfall.
Remember, power grows out of the muzzle of a gun!!
Lesson 1: Self Igniting Napalm Bomb
Fill a large glass container with a mixture of equal amounts . . .
When the bottle is thrown at a hard surface it shatters, allowing the components to mix and ignite spontaneously. The jellied petrol will stick to surrounding surfaces.
Remember, war is the continuation of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.
—Who published the leaflet?

—I have no idea but I shall have something to say about that in my question. Would the Minister not agree from internal evidence in this scurrilous document-such as the phrases 'We must hit the white man where it hurts him, in his pocket. We must use every means in our power, including direct action, to cause his downfall. Remember, power grows out of the muzzle of a gun. Remember, war is the continuation of politics'-that these phrases in no way represent the thinking of responsible Aboriginal people in Australia, and show strong signs of being the work of an agent provocateur seeking to discredit the Aboriginal people on the eve of the Commonwealth Games? Does the Minister not agree that the dissemmination in such a way of a purported recipe for a napalm weapon is grossly provocative, totally irresponsible, a libel of the Aboriginal people, and probably also a criminal incitement to violence? Will the Minister direct the Australian Federal Police to inquire into this matter with the objectives of identifying the originators of the pamphlet and taking whatever action is possible against them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly this is an outrageous document. Clearly it also does not have the support of the majority of Aboriginal people. Certainly I know that Stephen Foley, for one, has dissociated himself from this document. It is, as Senator Mason stated, designed to incite action of the most violent kind, something that could not be expected in Australia. The Government will take whatever action is possible to ensure that the kind of events referred to do not occur during the Commonwealth Games.

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Police have knowledge of this document; it has been before them. They are conducting inquiries as to the originators of it. There is no information available on that at present. I understand that copies of the circular have been sent to police forces throughout Australia, and also in New Zealand. Consequently all forces are on alert as to any possible action or outbreak that might occur as a result. If any further information becomes available from time to time, I shall make that available to Senator Mason.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Minister for Social Security, and being previously responsible for Aboriginal affairs, Senator Chaney has indicated considerable interest in a program of development to encourage viable self-management in remote areas, particularly concerning Aboriginal employment, in line with the Federal Government's policy of self-sufficiency for Aborigines. I understand that the work of the Joint Working Party on Job Training for Aboriginals has now been completed for a year or more and that the Government believes that the Community Development Employment Project has proved to be lacking in particular areas in its application. Will the Minister give consideration to forming separate joint authorities of the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government, and other States, to overcome overlapping of funding and programs which would include Aboriginal participation and to bring about a comprehensive, efficient and flexible training and employment program which could be applied to individual Aboriginal groups and communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question raised by the honourable senator touches on a number of portfolios, in particular, I suppose, my own, as it is my Department which has the responsibility of administering unemployment benefit. Also the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs administers a number of programs, including that referred to in the question, the Community Development Employment Project-a program which provides funds to communities to enable them to provide employment in lieu of unemployment. The amount of funds available is the amount of unemployment benefit plus a small additional percentage payment to cover overheads and materials. In his question Senator Kilgariff suggested that the Government believes that the CDEP has proved to be lacking in some areas. I think it would be fair to say that the results of the Community Development Employment Project have been somewhat uneven. Some Aboriginal communities-I think Elcho Island is one-have found the CDEP very beneficial. There have been others--
—And the Torres Strait.

—Senator Baume, who of course has had responsibilities in this area too, has just reminded me of Torres Strait communities which seem to get particular benefit from the CDEP. I think it would be unfair to suggest that the Government sees that program as being a failure. Rather we see it as a program which has had very good results in some communities and poor results in others. However, I confess to the Senate that over a period of years and, indeed, since I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1978 to 1980, I have been concerned about the overall administration of Commonwealth programs in this area. It is a matter which has been the subject of a whole series of discussions between Senator Baume and me, Senator Baume and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and various Ministers who have responsibilities that impinge in this area. There have also been discussions at departmental head level. Those discussions have got us to the point where we still have the CDEP within the programs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and where we have a series of arrangements for the bulk payment of unemployment benefit to communities which seek some form of bulk payment. That bulk payment is often used in very much the same way as CDEP funding.

ANSWER.PARA: We are still examining the matter to see whether a more satisfactory overall approach can be devised. In that regard at this stage I simply acknowledge the suggestion Senator Kilgariff has made that we need some form of joint authority from the Federal Government, the Northern Territory and other States to overcome overlapping of funding and so on. I think I should express some interest in that because certainly the officers of my Department with whom I have had discussions over recent months-that is, officers working in the Northern Territory-have expressed concern about the co-ordination and overlapping of programs. The result of those discussions has been to reopen discussions on this subject between the now Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Ian Wilson, and me. I will, therefore, take into account in the course of those discussions the suggestion Senator Kilgariff has made. I think we would probably find unanimity in this chamber for the idea that it would be desirable, wherever possible, to provide some form of employment in remote Aboriginal communities rather than the simple payment of sit-down money which is so often so destructive. I think we would all agree that in principle we want to see the programs of the Commonwealth and of the Northern Territory Government co-ordinated so that there is as little confusion and overlap as possible. I agree that we have some way to go in meeting our various objectives, including those two broad objectives I have named. I will certainly take Senator Kilgariff's suggestion into account in my consideration of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Acting Treasurer that on 17 August this year by way of a question I outlined the actions of a Sydney tax consultancy service which offers its mainly ethnic clientele refunds on their income tax returns before they are lodged with the Australian Taxation Office in exchange for the clients signing over the proceeds of their income tax refund entitlements to the agency. I then proceeded to point out to the Minister that these clients were being ripped off by the agency as the legitimate tax refunds were usually worth a great deal more than the original sum paid to the unsuspecting client by the agency. Is the Minister aware that the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, the Honourable Paul Whelan, on 24 August this year in answering a question asked by Mr Webster, the member for Wakehurst in the State Parliament, named the taxation consultant involved, Mr J. Dekanic of Newtown, and read out statutory declarations detailing the agency's disreputable operations? Is the Minister also aware that the New South Wales Minister wrote to the Treasurer on that same day urging him to take action immediately to put an end to the agency' s unscrupulous practices? Finally, when will the Treasurer outlaw this type of exploitive taxation practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall the earlier question. I am not aware of the statement of the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs. The earlier question was referred to the Treasurer in the normal way. I would undertake to see what information he is able to provide on it. As I said at the time, there is the likelihood that those who act as tax agents have the assessment and any cheque or adjustment mailed to them. I have had no information on what arrangements they have made in this instance with their clients. But I will see whether there can be an early response to the earlier question and the question today.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the suggestion last week by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that half of the recently announced tax cuts should be forgone and the amount saved should be used to set up a fund to provide jobs for the unemployed. I ask the Minister: Is this the first public recognition by the trade union movement of the linkage between unemployment and excessive benefits to those in work and, while accepting that the ACTU scheme would not achieve the objects it claims, is there not something there which would help our search for a fair wage system which would match our present economic situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like other members of the Government and no doubt members of the community, was interested to see the proposition put forward by the ACTU last week which included as one of its elements the proposition that there should be some forgoing of tax cuts and the funds thereby made available should be used to provide jobs for the unemployed. Senator Hamer asks whether this is the first public recognition by the trade union movement of the linkage between unemployment and excessive benefits to those in work. My response to that would be to say that, whilst it may be the first formal acknowledgement of that linkage by the trade union movement in Australia, I think there has been some informal acknowledgement of it in some recent wage settlements which have in a number of cases been on a basis which is rather less than one would have expected over recent years and where there has been, I think, in that practical sense, an acknowledgement by trade unions that wage rises which outstrip increases in productivity are likely to be counterproductive, and, I suppose, a welcome return to the view which was put by Frank Crean that in some circumstances one man's wage rise can be another man's job.

ANSWER.PARA: I return to the ACTU proposition of last week. That was the first formal recognition by the union movement that excessive wage increases are one of the factors contributing to our current economic difficulties and an acknowledgment of the importance of curbing unemployment. It does stand in some contrast to previous formal announcements by the movement which have tended to focus more on increasing the incomes of people in employment with little recognition of any responsibility of the union movement to the unemployed.

The Government certainly has no quarrel with the basic objective to increase employment. Indeed, that is its fervent wish. We do have some concerns with the nature of the ACTU proposal and with its timing. It is a matter of regret, for example, that a proposal with as many suggestions that are relevant to budgetary consideration should have been put last week after the Budget rather than at the 7 July tripartite conference which was held by the Government to provide an opportunity for employers, trade unions and the Government to consider the very significant economic difficulties which face the country. Another difficulty is that it is a precondition of the ACTU plan that there should be government support for the maintenance of real wages which is probably something which could not be undertaken in the present economic circumstances if we are to increase employment. There are, of course, a number of practical problems, including whether the ACTU is in a position to speak for the whole of the working people of Australia in offering to forgo tax reductions which have been pretty eagerly sought by the great bulk of Australians. But I think the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has indicated that he is willing to discuss the proposal further with the ACTU if it wishes. I think the original statement of the Acting Minister, Mr N. A. Brown, did make the same point that he was prepared to have discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he did not.

—The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has been in contact with the President of the ACTU and has made it clear that the offer stands-that is the offer originally put forward by Mr Brown-and that he is prepared to meet the ACTU, discuss the plan and try to put some flesh on its bones to see how relevant it might be in the preparation of next year's Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government maintains the view that wage restraint in the present economic circumstances is essential if sustainable economic growth is to be achieved. By interjection the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate denied that Mr Brown had offered to discuss the ACTU offer. I refer to page 3 of the Press release which was issued by Mr Brown on 3 September, which states:

If the ACTU wishes to have discussions with Government on the proposals it has put forward, then the Government is willing to do so. However, such discussions would need to be on the clear understanding of the importance the Government attaches to wage restraint in present economic circumstances.

As a participant in the tripartite discussions which took place in Canberra in July, I believe it is important that we maintain a dialogue with employers and the trade union movement. There are problems which I believe cannot be solved by government alone, by employers alone or by the trade union movement alone. I believe therefore that those opportunities for dialogue should be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of the case of the Commonwealth v. Brown, a decision of the Supreme Court of Victoria on 7 May 1982 and reported in Volume 13 of the Australasian Tax Reports at page 1? Is the Attorney aware that this case concerns the liquidation of a company which had been involved in a blatant tax avoidance scheme with money being channelled in a round-robin way through a series of companies involving at one crucial stage a spurious donation of $1.6m to the Norfolk Island Public Art Gallery, the exercise being in order to avoid the payment of what was assessed at $105,000 in tax? Is the Attorney further aware that Mr Justice Crockett directed at the conclusion of the judgment he delivered over four months ago that his reasons for judgment be drawn to the attention of, among others, the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth? Can the Attorney assure the Senate that his attention has been drawn to that case and that he has personally taken steps to ensure that this instance of tax avoidance is diligently investigated and that appropriate legal action is taken?

—I have not seen the case to which Senator Evans referred. I will make some enquiries as to whether the matter has been drawn to the attention of my Department. I will take note of what Senator Evans has said.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to the fact that the funeral benefit for ex-servicemen is to be increased from 1 November. I might add that this is a very worthwhile benefit for ex-servicemen's beneficiaries. In view of the small number of cases involved, will the Minister consider taking up with Cabinet the chance of making those payments retrospective-I suppose that is the in word-to the day of the Budget? Perhaps the same action could be applied to other increases that come along in this area and in that of the Department of Social Security.

—The date of commencement of the new benefit-1 November-was determined by Cabinet after considering all the issues surrounding the matter. It is unfortunate but I have to say to Senator Townley that there is no way in which that matter can be raised by Cabinet at this stage of the game, nor is any change contemplated. The benefit to which the honourable senator referred is very significant. It follows a significant increase in the funeral benefit last year-from $300 to $400. This further rise of $100 to $500 represents a very significant benefit for relatives of veterans who unfortunately died owing to their war caused disabilities. It is a policy of the Government to continue to review the amount of the funeral benefit. I can give Senator Townley an undertaking that the Government will continue to do that in the lead-up to subsequent Budgets.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not really said whether he will take the matter to Cabinet. He says it cannot be looked at again. There are only a small number of cases involved. If it cannot be done this year could I ask whether in future, as tax increases start from the day they are announced, increases in something with so few people involved could start from the day they are announced rather than several months later?
—I am prepared to take that suggestion on board and I will keep it in mind at the time of further discussions with Cabinet on the benefit.

—Is the Minister for Social Security concerned that the amount of unemployment benefit paid to young people between the ages of 15 years and 18 years has decreased in real terms by something like 40 per cent since 1975? How does the Minister expect young people living away from home to exist on the miserable sum of $40 a week? Is he at all concerned that this low benefit has contributed to the problems of homeless young people in the community and indeed forced many of them into prostitution? Will the Minister undertake to put pressure on the Prime Minister and other members of Cabinet to have the amount of benefit paid to 15 to 18-year-olds increased to a more realistic level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question raised by Senator Foreman is an important one and it is difficult to answer it shortly. Indeed, if he looks at the recent report on homeless youth by the Senate Standing Committe on Social Welfare he will see some of the complexities of this matter, and the fact that that all-party Committee reported unanimously-although some honourable senators have put a slight gloss on the report since in speeches in this chamber-that there really are no simple solutions to the significant problem which he has raised. It is true that since 1975 the holding of the rate of unemployment benefit for the under 18-year-olds has effected a diminution in its real value. That is a fact. The Budget this year contains an increase. The level of benefit is to rise from $36 to $40 a week in November.

ANSWER.PARA: In examining this matter the Government has not looked at the problem in isolation. Over recent years the Ministers with responsibilities relevant to that group, and principally the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs-as he then was-the Minister for Education and the Minister for Social Security have looked at their proposals affecting the 15 to 18-year-old group in common as part of the Budget process. I speak from memory now but I think the statistics roughly show that we have 750,000 Australians in that age group. Of that number about 500,000 are in education. We would welcome that, of course, and believe that if anything that number should be increased. Something like 200,000 are in employment and about 50,000-I say about because the figures may have varied a little recently-are unemployed. We have to examine the alternatives available to people in that age group. We would see unemployment as being the worst alternative. We have looked at the education allowances-the current Budget made significant improvements in them, both with respect to secondary assistance and the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme-because we do wish to encourage the maximum number of those people to increase their skills and remain in education. Obviously we see employment as the next best option. In that regard I think we have made a 25 per cent increase this year in training allowances and the sorts of subsidies to employers which will help to reduce the barriers between that group and employment.

In the final and worst alternative, that of being unemployed and on unemployment benefit, we have to try to maintain a situation where the unemployment benefit is not seen as a significantly better financial alternative to the other alternatives available to youth. So we have tried to ensure that there is not an imbalance between the incentives for young people either to remain in education or to be employed or to be on the dole. The great bulk of the age group that Senator Foreman mentioned in his question live at home. A recent Australian Bureau of Statistics survey shows that something in excess of 80 per cent of the age group he mentioned remain living at home with their parents. Again, that is a matter we would wish to encourage. We believe that the maintenance of some parental responsibilities for people who are still very young is desirable and it does colour the extent to which we should have benefits which might be trying to show that these people are automatically to be regarded as fully dependent.

Having said that, there remains a problem and the problem is that a relatively small number of people in that age group who are independent are, for a variety of reasons-some of them because they have been rejected by their families, some because perhaps they are adventurous and have simply left home-living away from home and trying to survive on at present $36 a week, soon to be $40 a week. The Government acknowledges that this is a problem.

What approach is to be adopted? In the current Budget we simply adjusted the benefit and, in acknowledging that the problem remains, we also produced additional funds for the Youth Services Scheme. There was an increase of $500, 000 in the funding which was offered to the States for that scheme-a rise from approximately $1.3m to $1.8m for the current financial year. That is matched money and will, I think, enable a significant maintenance of effort among homeless youth.

In addition, for the first time the Government made available to my Department some additional money-I think the figure is $300,000-which will enable us to provide some additional assistance to those agencies which are working among the homeless unemployed youth. That figure really relates, I think, to additional assistance of about $10 per week per child who has been away from home for more than about eight or 10 weeks. It is meant to be a sort of interim measure of assistance while the Government considers the report of the Senate Committee, while the Government considers the report of the evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme and while we further consider what are the appropriate policies for that age group that Senator Foreman has mentioned-the under 18-year-olds.

I am sorry to respond at length but this matter is not a simple one. I want the Senate to be quite clear that the Government, across a range of departments, has addressed itself to the problem. It sees the maintenance of incentives for students to remain in education as very important. It sees the maintenance of programs which will bridge the gap between those who have left school and employment as important. It sees the maintenance of effort in the social security area, particularly the maintenance of effort among agencies working with that group, as very important. I think that approach by the Government is in broad in line with the all-party approach adopted by the Senate Committee. I can assure the Senate that the matter that Senator Foreman has raised is receiving continuing attention. It will be the subject of discussion among officials at the Commonwealth-State administrators meeting which I understand will be held in October. It will certainly be the subject of discussion between Commonwealth and State Ministers at the welfare Ministers conference in February . I can only say that I think we are making some progress in this vexed area but there are still answers to be found.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health noted an item in the Sydney Morning Herald of a few days ago reporting on a recent study of more than 2,500 school children in New South Wales. It is alleged that the survey has established that up to one third of these children have early signs of coronary heart disease and chronic lung diseases. Dr Andersen, one of the main researchers, said that he did not know whether the figures were representative or really accurate. According to the newspaper article Dr Andersen further said:

QUESTION.PARA: We feel there was significant under-reporting by the Sydney children.

Will the Minister approach the Department of Health to obtain an opinion of what is the real position in regard to this very important question of the health conditions of such a significant number of our young people? What action will the Department take to publicise the findings of the survey in order to warn parents to take all the necessary care for their children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which drew attention to the health of school children in respect of the early signs of a number of degenerative diseases. I presume that is the article to which Senator Lajovic referred. It seems to me that many of the degenerative diseases which plague our society develop during life. It is not surprising that children, particularly those whose lifestyle is unsatisfactory in some way, may show some early signs. I imagine that the factors which would have to do with the evidence revealed in the survey mentioned by Senator Lajovic would include smoking, obesity, dietary factors and lack of exercise if, indeed, that was a characteristic of the group. It merely brings home once again that the main area of reversible illness in Australia that we have to approach concerns lifestyle- induced diseases and that many of the solutions to these problems do not rest with better hospital facilities but with a better lifestyle and better advice.

ANSWER.PARA: I will certainly approach the Department of Health, as Senator Lajovic has sought, with a view to getting the best figures that are available on the health of Australian school children, particularly as they may relate to the presence of risk factors or to the evidence of illness.

I mention to the honourable senator that recently in the Senate I was asked about nutritional advice. I was able to advise then of some work being carried on through the National Health and Medical Research Council and one of its sub- committees in which nutritional advice is being given more widely. Of course, honourable senators will be aware of the emphasis on healthy lifestyle factors generally through departments of Health, certainly through programs such as the one that was mounted through the Health Commission of New South Wales some years ago in Lismore and not least, of course, through programs which are being promoted within this Parliament for those of us who have the honour to serve as parliamentarians. While I cannot guarantee that the evidence which appeared in the newspaper report was accurate, I have no doubt that the thrust of what was being presented is correct; that we do have a problem and that the way to approach it is to try to attack lifestyle factors and to promote exercise and a healthy diet in that group of children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen recent Press reports of a statement on housing being published by the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace entitled 'House and Home: a Christian call for Housing Justice'? Is the Minister aware that the statement calls for concerted action under a national housing policy to give priority to improving housing conditions for the poorest? How does the Government's policy of spending $415m on tax rebates for home owners, irrespective of their income or housing needs, square with the priorities enunciated in the Catholic Commission's statement and with the Minister's own announced priorities for social welfare generally? What action does the Government now intend to take in response to the clear need to redress the woeful inadequacies in its housing policy, particularly as they relate to those most in need of assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am familiar with Press articles on the report which has been put out by the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace. I think it has been made available to me but I have not yet had a chance to study it. But I am aware of the broad points made by it which, as I understand it, are along the lines raised by Senator Giles in her question. She asked about the priority given to improving access to housing for the poorest. I remind the Senate that there was indeed an acknowledgment of the difficulties in this area not immediately in the Budget, although of course it is part of the Budget provision, but prior to that at the Premiers Conference when the Commonwealth announced a considerable increase in the funds made available for welfare housing. The increase for this year is a 27 per cent increase over last year and all of the increase is in the form of non-repayable grants.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, at the time of the Premiers Conference, the Commonwealth indicated to the States that it was prepared to allow the States, if they diverted additional parts of their housing and works programs to housing, to receive the loan moneys at concessional interest rates. In other words, the States not only were given additional funds-indeed a 27 per cent increase over last year-but also were encouraged to divert additional funds of their own. The encouragement is fairly considerable since the money is made available at, I think, a 50-year term with an interest rate of something like 4 1/2 per cent. In Australia in 1982, they are pretty attractive terms. I know that a number of States, including my State of Western Australia, showed great interest in this. I understand that a series of States have been able to lift their welfare housing effort as a result. So, in fact, in the field referred to by the honourable senator the Government has sought to respond to the problem. The response has been in the form of cold hard cash.

However, the question also raises the question whether, at the same time, we should be providing relief to home buyers through tax concessions on interest payments. It is fallacious to look at any Budget from one point of view only, whether it be the welfare, defence or any other point of view. In framing the Budget the Government has to look at the range of requirements of the Australian community. Unless Senator Giles is woefully out of touch with her electorate and suburban Australia she would be aware that many modest Australians, who regard themselves as not wealthy, feel that current interest rates exert real pressure upon them. I believe that they would resist any suggestion which might be made by Senator Giles that they do not warrant assistance or relief in the current circumstances.

The fact that there has been some interest relief through the tax mechanism would be widely welcomed by the 70 per cent or so of Australians who own their own homes. Many of them would have seen that as providing fairly important, perhaps essential, relief, given recent increases in interest rates. In a Budget which has to take account of the needs of all Australia I point to the fact that there has been a 15 per cent increase in the appropriation for my Department. After one takes into account the fact that this is a 26 pay-days year, rather than a 27 pay-days year such as we had last year, this represents an 18 per cent real increase in the proposed effective expenditure of my Department. I point also to the 27 per cent increase in the welfare housing field and the interest concessions offered to the State governments to encourage the increased provision of welfare housing. I point also to the doubling of assistance in regard to the emergency accommodation for families program. There have also been significant increases in the provision for the aged and disabled persons housing program. The Government acknowledged the difficulties in the low income housing area. We do not claim that the problems have been solved but would claim that in the current Budget provision we have made most significant contributions to reducing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the honourable senator 's implication that I am out of touch with the needs of the electors in Western Australia in regard to housing, I repeat that part of my question which refers to the money provided for tax rebate purposes. I included a reference to the fact that it had been allocated irrespective of income or housing need. I ask again: How does the Government's policy on rebates for home owners, irrespective of income or housing need, square with priorities enunciated by the statement of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like Senator Giles to be under the impression that I am trying to imply that she is out of touch. After hearing her repeat her question, I think I would state bluntly that she is indeed out of touch with her electorate. As I tried to explain at some length in the answer to her question-I am conscious of Opposition complaints about long answers-the Budget has to be framed to take account of a wide range of needs and requirements in the community. I pointed out that my own Department, which deals with a substantial proportion of the community which is in need, has been granted very significant increases in proposed expenditure. I referred also to the very significant increases in proposed expenditure on those programs which relate to housing for people who are on low incomes.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the broad assistance which has been given to all home buyers in Australia is concerned-it is important to note that all home buyers still paying mortgage interest will receive relief under the current Budget-I remind Senator Giles that the recent increases in interest rates have imposed a real degree of hardship on many who would not have regarded themselves, in any sense, as being welfare cases. I believe there will be massive agreement among them that those changes were needed. The definition of need is very elastic. I point out that those who argue the poverty case will always say that hardship is a relative matter. I would say that in suburban Australia there has been a degree of relative hardship which has been of concern to the community. It has been of concern to the Government also and I do not believe that the Government has to be apologetic for granting relief in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation advise the Senate whether aviation regulations specify the compulsory use of high lead 100 octane aviation fuel in light aircraft in Australia? Under the same regulations, is the use of standard grade motor spirit forbidden? If so, what are the reasons for the ban? Is the Minister aware of problems which the high lead fuels are causing in light aircraft engines, involving the undertaking of more extensive work at the compulsory 100 hours service? Is the Minister further aware that the use of standard grade motor spirit for light aircraft can alleviate these problems and, from some reports, is a more satisfactory aviation fuel? Finally, is the Minister aware that standard grade petrol is used as aviation fuel elsewhere in the world without problems? If so, will the Government take steps to reassess the regulations governing aviation fuel in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on this subject. I am advised that the Air Navigation Regulations require the owner, operator or pilot in command to use the grade of fuel specified in the aircraft flight manual unless otherwise approved by the Secretary to the Department of Aviation. It follows that the regulations prohibit the use of any other kind of fuel. The fuel grade or grades specified in the flight manual are those for which the aircraft and the engine manufacturer have shown compliance of the engine and aircraft with safety design standards. Some light aircraft flight manuals specify grade 100 to 130 aviation fuel as the only approved fuel. The Secretary to the Department has advised that grade 100LL-I understand that that stands for low lead-aviation fuel is an alternative. Some light aircraft flight manuals specify grade 80 to 87 aviation fuel. This fuel is no longer available in Australia and the Secretary has approved the use of grade 100 to 100LL aviation fuel as an alternative.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department is aware of the problems to which Senator Crichton-Browne has drawn attention in respect of the maintenance of some engines. Some engine manufacturers are aware of supply difficulties with low octane fuel and have recommended engine modifications to counteract some of the difficulties with the use of higher octane grades of aviation fuel. I understand that advisory circulars are issued to operators in the industry on all those various measures.

There are safety problems with the use of motor spirit in aircraft engines primarily because of the higher volatility of motor spirit and the differences in specifications and quality control of motor spirit and aviation gasolene. As far as is known, the use of motor spirit overseas has been on a very limited basis. I understand that in the United Kingdom it is permitted in a limited range of light aircraft with temperature limits which are unsuitable for the Australian climate. The United Kingdom also has special quality control on the fuel provided in this way. The only known approval in the United States of America has been for use in experimental categories of aircraft. The Minister and the Department are aware of moves in Australia to have motor spirit approved for use in aircraft. The Aviation Industry Advisory Committee has recently been formed and an ad hoc working group, with representatives of the Department of Industry and Commerce, is currently being set up to advise on the use of motor spirit in light aircraft. The working group is monitoring activity on this subject from overseas and is awaiting the outcome of experimental work being done on the subject within this country.

The honourable senator can be assured that the Minister and his Department are aware of the problems in regard to the supply of the various grades of aviation gasolene and will be approving alternative sources when it can be guaranteed that the appropriate safeguards are available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I heard a radio comment by the New South Wales Attorney-General on this matter this morning. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is the Minister aware that the management of Telecom Australia is proposing to close the public terminal for telegram and telex services at the Brisbane General Post Office? Is the Minister aware that in the whole of Queensland this is the only public facility where a telegram or a telex can be sent 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and that this service has existed for the benefit of the people of Queensland since Federation? In view of the great importance to individuals in times of family crisis and of national disasters, whose only means of communication is a public facility, will the Minister ensure that at least this one facility remains in Brisbane? Furthermore, with the Commonwealth Games imminent, will the Minister ensure that action is taken immediately to retain this facility? Will he also see that adequate ISD telephone services, which are not available at present, become available in Brisbane before the Games?

—Senator MacGibbon raises a matter of concern to people in Brisbane. I imagine that it would be of interest to people in other cities who may want the same kind of access to facilities such as he set out. His questions are particular and I believe they should be referred to the Minister whom I represent in this place. I shall refer the questions, especially in view of the imminence of the Commonwealth Games. Because the question contains at least some reference to facilities for the Commonwealth Games, I shall undertake to try to get an early response for the honourable senator.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It has been stated in the media that the super-powers-Soviet Russia and the United States-are in a chemical weapons race. In an article in the journal The Progressive, volume 46, of February this year, by David H. Morrissey , entitled 'The Return of Chemical Warfare', he states that Australians took part in the chemical training school at Fort McClellan in the United States. How many Australians were sent for training at the McClellan Chemical School in the United States, and for how long and for what purpose? Has Australia ratified the United Nations International Convention on Humane Methods of Warfare?
—I shall refer that question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide an early answer for the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Frequently Public Service addresses and telephone numbers which also appear in another section of the telephone book are cross-referenced, so that the only information given is 'refer to' or 'see item listed under' such and such. Will the Minister undertake to request Telecom Australia to examine this situation with a view to providing the full details of name, address and number in each listing, as frequently these important details are just as short as the referral?

—I am grateful to Senator Archer for that question. I sometimes have difficulty in trying to identify Public Service telephone numbers because the listings are often quite difficult to separate and numbers are difficult to find. Senator Archer asked a question about circumstances in which the numbers appear not in one place but in two or three places and the question of cross-referencing. That would be a matter for consideration by my colleague. I will undertake to make Senator Archer's concern known to him and attempt to obtain a response from Mr Brown.

—I ask the Attorney-General whether Mr Clem O'Sullivan, formerly the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth, after retiring from the position of Deputy Crown Solicitor, completed on a contract basis work he had partially completed while on the government payroll. How common is the practice of letting contract work and what procedures apply to its letting? Was Mr O'Sullivan selected to do this work because of his known diligence and administrative ability?

—I have not any information in relation to the matter Senator Walsh has raised about Mr Clem O'Sullivan who was the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth and who retired from that position several years ago. Senator Walsh asked whether Mr O'Sullivan completed on a contract basis work for the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth which he had been working on in his former role. I am aware that after Mr Clem O'Sullivan retired from the position of Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth he went into private practice as a member of the independent Bar in Western Australia. Of course it is very common and widespread practice for the Crown Solicitor to brief both senior and junior counsel all around Australia. Indeed, my Department probably makes more use of contract work in the sense of briefing to counsel than is normal throughout the government service. So there would not be anything surprising in Mr O'Sullivan being briefed for certain work. But I have no information about the particular work or the circumstances. I will have that matter inquired into and provide a detailed written answer for Senator Walsh as soon as possible.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Sturt's desert pea, which has the botanical name of Clianthus formosus, was first recorded by William Dampier in the north- west of Western Australia in 1699. Dried specimens of this plant can still be seen at Kew Gardens in London. The explorer Sturt first saw the plant in 1844, 145 years after Dampier discovered it. Will the Minister endeavour, through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other relevant authorities, to have the common name of the plant changed to Dampier pea? The famous botanist Alan Cunningham gave it the botanical name Clianthus dampieri. Most shires in the northern part of Western Australia use it as part of their official emblems. I believe that the change would be an appropriate way of marking the 300th anniversary in 1988 of the year William Dampier first landed in Australia.

—I do not know about other senators but I was certainly impressed by the wealth of botanical knowledge and expertise shown in the question. I understand that there are strict international rules governing the scientific names given to plants but that common names, such as Sturt's desert pea, are entirely a matter of local usage. My colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, may be able to ask the Bureau of Flora and Fauna, which advises him on the names of plants, to examine whether there would be any difficulty in recommending to the Australian public that this plant be called Dampier pea. That would be a matter of usage rather than a matter of scientific name. Mr President, as you would be well aware, the plant known as Sturt's desert pea was gazetted in 1961 as a floral emblem of South Australia.
—That is right.
—It would be appropriate, therefore, for the Government of South Australia-my colleague, Senator Messner, indicates his interest-to be fully consulted before any change of name was proposed.
—I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I table the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The recovery of tax evaded by vendors who sold company shares at prices which made no allowance for the company's contingent tax liability, and the need for the Senate to unequivocally support this action.

Tax cheats have been plundering $40 a week from the average Australian household . The time has come to make them give it back. For many years this larceny was viewed benignly by a Prime Minister whose fundamental instincts on this subject are similar to those of a former Chief Justice. For five years the present Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has supinely presided over non-enforcement of the law. For two and a half years the Treasurer (Mr Howard) watched the diversion of billions of dollars from the public revenue to the Liberal Party and other tax dodgers. He then limited the diversion but for another one and a half years did nothing to recover the money which had already been stolen.

In the last two months, spurred by fear of electoral retribution, the Government has proclaimed its intention to recover a tiny fraction of the money stolen by tax cheats. This tardy move has been denounced by a gaggle of Liberals , not because it is pusillanimous, which it is, but because it threatens to retrieve anything at all that has been stolen from those who have stolen it. The ganders of this gaggle include the Premier of Western Australia, Mr O'Connor; an endorsed Liberal Party candidate, Mr W. W. Mitchell; the President of the Liberal Party of Western Australia and its current bagman, Mr Ian Warner, and Mr Ian Collie, a Melbourne solicitor, who laundered Garland's companies for him in 1978.

The Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party is in open revolt. Last Tuesday the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) strutted around the House of Representatives impersonating a tough leader who had stood over the Liberal Party and imposed his will on them at the Liberal Party's Federal Council meeting. The Liberal Party President, Dr Forbes, has given identical assurances in letters published in all major newspapers. Yesterday, Western Australian Liberal Party President Warner dropped the bucket on them and revealed that the Prime Minister had in fact appeased the tax dodgers at the Liberal Party Council meeting by watering down the proposed legislation. He went further than that. He threatened to tell the world, to give the world a comprehensive account of what had in fact happened at that meeting. As my colleague Mick Young said in the House of Representatives a couple of days ago, we want the minutes of what happened at that Liberal Party meeting, not the Prime Minister's version of it or the official Press release.

This campaign to prevent the recovery from these thieves of a tiny fraction of the money they have stolen from Australian households and Australian taxpayers, a campaign to which the Prime Minister has already, to some degree, succumbed, so Mr Warner tells us, is supported by claims that the vendors of the companies or of the shares in the companies were innocent bystanders and therefore it is quite unfair to take back from them the money that they should not have had in the first place. It is difficult to imagine a more absurd proposition. It is like saying that if a bank robber has managed to keep a stolen payroll for a few years he should not have to give it back either. These people are getting off lightly. Many of them should be prosecuted under criminal law. All of them will pay back the tax that they have evaded after they have had the use of that money for many years and after inflation has eroded the real value of it.

The foremost exponent of this innocent bystander line is Denis Horgan, a tax dodger, a Liberal Party bagman and the holder of seven government offices. He was the principal shareholder of Treamog Pty Ltd which was flogged off to Maher in 1976 and which, in the process, evaded a $1.7m current year contingent tax liability. Denis Horgan's personal share through his direct and indirect holdings in the company was $1m. He has offered various excuses in public. He said that there was no current tax liability at the time the company was sold. That applies to almost all the companies that were flogged off to Maher and his ilk.

He said the company had plenty of money available, when he sold it, to pay the tax. Of course it had plenty of money. It had nothing but money. That is why the company was sold. It was sold because it was bursting with money. Horgan said he had no idea what Maher would do with the company after Maher had bought it and, therefore, he was an innocent bystander.

I wish to quote from the 1976 annual report of Metro Industries Pty Ltd, which was taken from the Corporate Affairs Office in Perth. Metro Industries was a shareholder in Treamog, the company that was sold. Metro described Treamog as an indirect subsidiary of Metro. The report states:
Treamog Ltd, 93.15%, representing net tangible assets of $4,068,583, was disposed of for a consideration of $5,799,267.

Net tangible assets of $4m were disposed of for a consideration of $5.7m. That $ 1.7m difference represents the tax that Denis Horgan and the other shareholders evaded. This was disclosed in the annual report of Metro Industries, a company of which Denis Horgan is also a shareholder. Horgan also claimed on another occasion that he had paid tax on the profit derived from the sale of Treamog through the other companies in which he also had an interest and of which he was a director which had derived profits from the sale. That might have been plausible if he had not flogged off three other companies to Maher and Donnelly, all of which were shareholders in Treamog. That is not necessarily an exhaustive list. We know of three other companies which he flogged off to Maher and Donnelly. The companies were Henderson Investments Pty Ltd, Norwood Investments Pty Ltd, and H.B.D. Holdings Pty Ltd. All of these companies, directly or indirectly, were major shareholders in Treamog, the company which was originally sold off. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard photostat copies of documents taken from the Corporate Affairs Office of Western Australia giving details of the directorial changes in those three companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Denis Horgan has the chutzpah to say that he did not rob the bank ; he just sold the robbers the get-away car. He sold four cars to the same robbers. He said that he could not tell the crooks but the crooks kept coming back to buy another car so that they could rob another bank. Because they are exempt companies we cannot get the full financial details of the other three companies I have named, which Horgan flogged off to Maher and Donnelly. They are incorporated in Perth. For the financial details of just how much extra tax he evaded on those companies we will have to wait for the election of a Labor government in Western Australia and the appointment of a McCabe-type investigation of the Corporate Affairs Office in Western Australia. That is something that will happen next year.
—That doesn't require a Labor government. It was a Liberal government which set up the inquiry in Victoria.

—A Liberal government might have done it in Victoria, but I guarantee a Liberal government will not do it in Western Australia. There would be too many skeletons lying around there. Some of them have now been deposited here. As well as being a multiple tax dodger who flogged off at least four companies to Maher and Donnelly-I might add that in one case at least he left the minority shareholders whistling for their money and set them up to be fleeced by these other crooks-this fellow has been the beneficiary of multiple government patronage. He currently holds seven government offices, including a directorship of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and a commissionership of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. When this matter was raised with the Treasurer a couple of weeks ago he said that just because someone is mentioned-I repeat the word 'mentioned'-in the McCabe-Lafranchi report does not mean he is not fit to hold government office. Mr Horgan was not just mentioned in the report. In the first place he was identified as a major beneficiary of the sale of a company for the deliberate intent of evading a contingent tax liability. We now know that he flogged off at least three other companies to the same crooks. Has the Treasurer asked Mr Horgan at any stage any questions about his multiple involvement with Maher and Donnelly, or does the Treasurer, like the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), not want to know about it?

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of weeks ago the Prime Minister said that he had ordered the tax dodgers to get out of the Liberal Party. If that really happened, the party would be able to hold its State conference in a backyard dunny, at least in Western Australia. But more importantly is the Prime Minister saying that he expects higher standards of personal propriety in the Liberal Party than he does in the Government over which he presides? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government fully supports the matter of urgency which has been moved in the Senate today. That does not mean that we support the language of Senator Walsh or the demeanour of Senator Walsh in moving what is a matter of urgency and of importance. The Government supports the matter of urgency because it encompasses the basic thrust of the Government's proposed legislation to recover from vendor shareholders the company tax that was evaded in bottom-of-the-harbour strips of untaxed company profits. In order to understand the Government's proposal to recover this evaded tax it is perhaps important to realise the true nature of such schemes. I do not know whether the talk of recent days puts clearly just what is the Government's proposal so I think I ought to do that right now.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike many other notorious schemes such as the Curran scheme, the bottom-of- the-harbour scheme did not involve sophisticated tax avoidance arrangements under which the liability for tax was avoided. On the contrary, it involved a case of outright and illegal evasion of tax in which most of the tax for which a company was liable ended up in the pockets of the people who sold the company. The companies concerned were simply put in a position where they had no assets to meet their tax liabilities. To this day those tax liabilities have not been met and are still outstanding.

The first step in the chain of events in this sort of operation was that the shareholders, known as the vendor shareholders, in a profitable company, known as the target company, sold their shares to a promoter who paid the full value of the target company's assets less his commission. Of course, the assets included funds which under normal circumstances should have been set aside to pay the target company's tax bill. Vendor shareholders thus received a sum of money considerably greater than that which they could reasonably have expected under a normal commercial sale because the promoter had no intention of paying the target company's tax liabilities. In a typical case, the promoter then transferred the company to men of straw-that is, people of no financial substance-or to fictitious persons or companies at fictitious addresses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or to painters and dockers.

— It could have been members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. At this point the company's records often, but not always, became untraceable; that is, they might well have been at the bottom of the harbour. That is the origin of the scheme's picturesque title. The Commissioner of Taxation might then have issued an assessment for income tax against the target company but the Commissioner could not succeed in collecting the taxes owed because the target company by then had no assets left to pay the bill. The new directors or owners of the target company were either completely fictitious, untraceable or else they were so-called men, or sometimes women, of straw. In the McCabe-Lafranchi report there was a vivid description of how some of these men of straw were recruited at race tracks by criminals and offered a free holiday in Brisbane in return for their signatures. One person recruited, a woman, was quoted as telling how she spent days signing cheques-some of them for $12m or $14m and one which she remembered for $74m. It is clear that at some point at least some, if not all, of the participants in this type of scheme intended to defraud the Commonwealth of money. That is, they intended that money , which should have been set aside as a provision for tax, in fact went into the pockets or bank accounts of the vendor shareholders and/or promoters. A very small part-literally a few dollars out of many millions-went to the men of straw who were induced to sign the forms, documents and cheques for a fee.

SPEECH.PARA: One might well ask what has been the action with regard to this. I remind the Senate that in 1980 the Government brought in special criminal legislation against these practices. The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act now makes it a criminal offence punishable by up to five years gaol and/or a fine of up to $50, 000 either to promote or to take part in these schemes. The Government was advised at the time that this special legislation was needed to deal effectively with the problem that had been identified. More recent legal advice has suggested that criminal law remedies against at least the promoters of these schemes were available under the law prior to December 1980. As announced by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his response to the Costigan report, proceedings under this law will be pursued with vigour through a special task force. But a great deal of revenue had already been lost to the Government-not in the sense that it was not owing to the Australian Taxation Office but in the sense that under ordinary, existing procedures it could not be recovered from the companies concerned. The very great amount of money involved has become apparent in the intervening period.

The McCabe-Lafranchi report commissioned by the Victorian Liberal Government was the first point at which names were put to the vendor shareholders of many of the bottom-of-the-harbour companies in Victoria. The New South Wales Government said later that it would hold a similar investigation. Today the Attorney-General of New South Wales made some statements in that regard. Ironically, the Federal Government, which was the principal victim of the scheme , could not provide names because of the strict secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which prevented the Commissioner from revealing any details of taxpayers' personal affairs. Whether or not it was strictly necessary, there can be no argument that the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act has proved a most effective deterrent to people contemplating bottom-of-the-harbour arrangements. But as evidence has mounted as to the true prevalence of the practice before the Act was passed and the sum of money outstanding to revenue as a result, the Government has been forced to consider whether it should take steps to recoup these debts to Commonwealth revenue. Therefore, it has announced that it will enact legislation to make the vendor shareholders-the people who sold their profitable companies to promoters-liable for the tax debt of the company. That is why we have no problem in supporting the matter of urgency. It is already the subject of an announcement and many statements by the Government. On 25 July, prior to the Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) made a statement outlining proposals to enact legislation to collect these funds and named the sums, as known to us at present, that would be collected.

A number of people have voiced concern about possible retrospective elements of the proposed legislation, but in considering that issue it is important to bear in mind that the legislation will not create a debt which was not previously owing. It will make vendors of the bottom-of-the-harbour companies-those who profited most from the schemes-liable to pay the tax assessed on the profits of the companies that they sold.

— The matters that we have been discussing are the subject of the legislation which has been foreshadowed by the Treasurer and which it is hoped to introduce in the Parliament within the next week or two.
