SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the vendor shareholder aspect, which is virtually the subject of this matter of urgency, it has been put by those who would argue against the proposed legislation that many vendor shareholders had no idea that after the sale of their shares the taxation liabilities of the companies would be illegally evaded. Indeed, it is understood that many vendor shareholders were counselled by their advisers not to ask questions about what was to happen. In other words, their ignorance of what was to happen after the sale would be their defence. On this issue it is worth noting that, as far back as September 1978, senior counsel advised that any prudent vendor would have satisfied himself about the intentions and capacity of purchasers regarding the payment of the company's tax before entering into the arrangement.

I repeat that the proposed legislation is the subject of a great deal of consideration and detailed discussion on the part of Government Ministers and their advisers. It will require each vendor shareholder to pay an amount equal to his or her share of the evaded company tax. The special tax would, of course, be refunded to the vendor shareholders if it should happen that, after the special tax has, in relation to a particular company, produced for the public purse an amount equivalent to the evaded company tax, proceedings against the promoter under the general law were to secure payment of the amount of the company tax itself.

The situations to which the special legislation will relate are those in which the shareholders of a company have together sold their shares in the company for a price that made it evident that company tax on profits that had by then arisen would not be paid. The shares, having been purchased from these shareholders, were typically sold in turn to other persons, culminating in their becoming owned by men of straw. The legislation will apply to the vendor shareholders in the first of these sales, but only where the company tax had not then, or has not since, been paid.

The legislation could be invoked only when the company tax liability was finally established, that is, when rights of objection and appeal had ceased to be available through the effluxion of time or had been exhausted, and assessments were final. Once the new special legislation has been enacted, the Commissioner will call on each vendor shareholder to pay an amount representing that person's share of the evaded tax. The way in which the proceeds of the sale of a company were split between the vendor shareholders will generally determine each shareholder's share of the evaded tax. A claim will not be made against the estate of a deceased person or against beneficiaries of that estate where, at the time the vendor shareholder died, a claim had not been made.

It will be immaterial whether the company tax has already been assessed, is assessed in the future or, as has happened in some cases, the target company has already been liquidated. Vendor shareholders will not be protected from the special liability by the target company having been put, in association with the strip, into a tax avoidance scheme, if that scheme is held not to be effective.

The legislation will not affect those people who sell their company at a commercially realistic price to new owners in whose hands the company becomes unable to pay its company tax due to commercial misadventure. Some vendor shareholders will have been companies, or will have held the shares as trustees. Beneficial ownership at the time of sale could have rested, perhaps through a chain of ownership, with others. The broad aim of the legislation in these situations will be to attribute the special tax liability to the people who have received the benefit of the proceeds of disposal of the shares concerned. An assessment will be due for payment 30 days after notice of its issue. Any amount of the special tax that remains unpaid after that date will carry the statutory penalty tax for late payment. The Government aims, by that level of penalty tax, to indicate its objective of recovering quickly the amounts of evaded tax. To underline that policy the penalty tax will be capable of remission only in the most exceptional circumstances. Assessments of the special tax will, of course, be subject to the usual rights of objection, review by an independent Taxation Board of Review and appeal to the courts.

The Government is confident that the action which it proposes to take will return very large amounts of outstanding revenue to where it belongs-the public purse on behalf of the Australian people. Not to take such action would be to confirm that the Government expects the average Australian taxpayer, particularly the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, to dig deeper into his pocket in order to meet the national debts and bills. At the same time, the tax evader would be permitted to enjoy the rights of citizenship and government services conferred by citizenship without contributing properly to costs. A number of difficult considerations are involved in this whole issue. The proposed legislation needs to be very carefully prepared. As I have said, it is the subject of very active consideration and work at present.

We believe that the confidence of the average citizen in the overall fairness of the taxation system can best be maintained by proceeding with recovery of the tax outstanding under these schemes. As I said earlier, we welcome the opportunity to talk about it and to build the community opinion to support the legislation when it is introduced. There has been a lot of public comment with regard to those who oppose the proposed legislation and it is very timely for the Senate to show that it can support what has been the announced policy and foreshadowed legislation of the Government.

The statement issued by the Treasurer towards the end of July indicated that the amount of revenue to be collected is estimated to be about $450m. That figure may grow as we proceed further into this activity but that amount was identified by our advisers at the time of preparing the Budget. That amount is significant and those of us looking at the matter closely would consider that it will grow. Certainly it is an amount that we would expect to be collected and one that we believe the proposed legislation will make it simpler to collect and possibly more secure as far as receipt into the Commonwealth revenue is concerned. For those who are interested, details of the proposal are in the statement of the Treasurer of 25 July. There are also the further statements made by those speaking on behalf of the Government on matters of public importance in the Parliament. It was stated that it is expected that a couple of hundred million dollars can be expected to emerge this year from legislation to recover from vendor shareholders the tax that was evaded in the bottom-of-the- harbour strips of untaxed company and Division 7 profits carried out before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980 made such conduct a specific criminal offence under Commonwealth law.

The fraud involved in these transactions was always a fraud as it involved offences against companies Acts and crimes Acts. The proposed legislation to recoup the proceeds of these frauds does not create any retrospective offence. It was always an offence, and that offence is one that has resulted in tax not being properly paid. It does not make illegal something that was legal at the time when these arrangements were entered into; it simply seeks to recoup the proceeds of these frauds from those who benefited from the frauds which were perpetrated by promoters who did not themselves benefit to any great degree apart from their relatively modest commissions. The promoter simply charged a fee-in many cases as small as 3 per cent-for arranging the fraud, with or without some of the beneficiaries knowing that it was a fraud. The fact remains that the benefit was passed to the vendors of the companies involved and it is these vendors who are now being obliged to repay the money that they received as a result of these fraudulent acts by the promoters with whom they associated.

The dilemma that has faced the Government is a simple one. Whilst it has been keen to proceed against the promoters, and such action is now being pursued, it is evident that no real revenue benefits will emerge. The advice the Government received-that the only way to protect the interests of the taxpayers who actually pay their taxes and whose burden is naturally higher because of the evasion of the responsibilities of the people in these schemes-was to seek recoupment from those who benefited from the schemes. Much has been made of the argument about retrospectivity. One hears all sorts of general comments, general attitudes, being stated against retrospective legislation. It has been said that it is immoral to introduce retrospective legislation or what can be termed retrospective charges on those who believed they had legally avoided taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't the promoters be investigated and prosecuted for unpaid taxes?

— I think that is so but in most cases the people who profited from them were those who had the largest benefit. The only reason why the tax was avoided was that an illegal device was used, by fraud, and the company arrangements were introduced under which the vendor shareholders received cash which was far greater than they could properly be entitled to receive unless an illegal act was involved. That is the basis of what we are talking about. They are now being required by this proposed legislation to give back the money to those to whom it properly belongs-that is, the Australian people. It does not mean that people who sold companies at higher than their asset backing are at risk; it is only those cases where the companies acknowledge tax liability were evaded by fraud that will be covered by the proposed legislation.

With thousands of millions of dollars in the hands of unscrupulous criminals, our legal and political system as a whole cannot be considered safe from corruption.

Mr Costigan has decribed the workings of the criminal system in chilling detail . First, there are the investors who supply the capital. They do so at arm's length but knowing full well they are a party to secret crimes. Secondly, there are the financial and managerial experts who assemble the funds and put them to use in an organised manner. The third tier is the group to which Senator Peter Rae just referred-the shyster lawyers and accountants-which provides assistance for the scheme itself and assistance whenever it or any of its participants run into trouble with law enforcement agencies. Finally, there are the criminal operatives, the cosh merchants, the people who carry guns, the drug pushers, the enforcers and the couriers.

The urgency motion before the House addresses itself to one sector of the tax evasion industry, the large number of tax evasion schemes collectively known as bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. There are many variations on the theme. I gave an example of one oversimplified scheme yesterday. Today, because we are not on air , I wish to give another variation of the theme which is not quite so simple but one that I believe is closer to reality. I take the example of a legitimate trading company with substantial current year profits, and therefore having an obvious tax liability, which is cashed up. That means that all assets, including the goodwill, stock and equipment and the liabilities, are transferred to a newly incorporated company. I will call that company A1 because usually in these schemes the new company was registered with a very similar name to the original company, The new company, A1, carries on the normal business of the original company A. Company A, the original company, retains only cash in the bank equal to the accumulated and current year profits. The name of the company is then changed to Z. All shares in the company are sold and new directors are appointed . The cash in the bank account of company Z is withdrawn totally by the directors as a dividend or as an intercompany transaction but, most often, by way of a loan. The money is eventually paid to the original shareholders and the promoter as payment for the shares of the company, usually via a financier. At best the company books would show a bad debt to the financier. In most cases, the books are destroyed by being burned or sent to the bottom of the harbour.

It will be seen from this example that the original shareholders either must have known or had some inkling of a shonky deal or, at best, a wilful scheme to evade tax illegally. There is no doubt about that. That is the case to which the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) eloquently referred today . I commend her and the Government on the statement that she made today insofar as it goes. We were very pleased with what she said with one reservation which I will come to in a moment. This is in the spirit of what Senator Peter Rae just said.

It is in this spirit that we certainly and vigorously support the matter of urgency moved by the Australian Labor Party. We will vote for it. I hope the House does come to a vote on the matter. In other words, we assume that the Labor Party, having used the word 'evaded' in the first line of its motion, means that there was a wilful and conscious intent on the part of the vendor shareholders to evade illegally their proper tax liability. I assume that is the position. I listened carefully to the Minister and I did not hear that component put into the set of circumstances which she described. That is not a criticism at this stage because I can understand the difficulty of the draftsmen and Cabinet in coming to draw up this kind of legislation. It must be one of the most difficult propositions faced by Cabinet in years. It must be extremely difficult to draw up the sort of legislation which will be fair and cover all points. However, the so-called retrospective legislation currently being drafted by the Government must be done with extreme caution so that it does not punish innocent people who sell shares in companies for quite respectable, reputable and genuine reasons, and people who have absolutely no intention of defrauding the Commonwealth or evading their proper tax liabilities.

I return to the oversimplified example which I gave yesterday where a man and his wife own a company which has a successful year. Let us say that it makes a profit of $100,000 and has a tax liability at the end of that year of $46,000. So its equity is $54,000. Someone comes along and says: 'I will give you $60,000 or $70,000 for it'. I can understand circumstances where a man and his wife, not versed in income tax law or whatever, could say: 'This man is not exactly Father Christmas but this seems to be a genuine and a generous offer. We are both in our late 50s and we are thinking of retiring. We have a pretty prosperous business'. Why should they not sell that company to this promoter-Mr C, or whoever it is-at a reasonable profit? That could well have happened in 1972, 10 years ago. Those two people would now be in their middle to late 60s, retired and in some humble little cottage at Gosford or whatever. I wonder about the equity of those people. I would assume that there would be some people who would suddenly get hit with a bill of $46,000. That is why I hope the Government has, in preparing this legislation, given thought to the conscious and wilful intent on the part of vendor shareholders. It seemed to me, on listening to the Minister this morning, that the Government is going to open up a whole embracing section which will mean that any vendor shareholder who sold shares without any thought to the payment of tax is going to be caught in the end and that the onus of proving that he or she is innocent will rest entirely on them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Peter Rae

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it may help if I quote something the member for Macarthur, Mr Baume, said on behalf of the Government in the other chamber. He said:

INTERJECT.PARA: This does not mean that all people who sold companies at higher then their assets backing are at risk; it is only in those cases where the companies' tax liabilities were evaded by fraud--
and so it goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Peter Rae for reading that into my speech. I do not think I am doing the Minister an injustice by saying that she did not say that this morning. That is not necessarily a criticism of the Minister. But I am grateful to Senator Peter Rae for his interjection. We support the Australian Labor Party's urgency motion, for reasons eloquently described by Claude Forell in yesterday's Melbourne Age. Our support is based on the contention that bottom -of-the-harbour schemes are and were unlawful at the time when they were committed. People may have been lulled into feelings of security by lack of prosecution but this does not mean that they were or are innocent and that the tax evaded by them should not be recovered. I quote Mr Forell, who is a journalist for whom I have an unbounded admiration. In talking about these schemes, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: They involved the deliberate evasion of company tax through the contrivance of artificial schemes peddled by promoters who took a commission and used criminals to dispose of the asset-stripped companies.

As Mr Costigan . . . pointed out, the schemes flourished not because they were legal at the time but because existing laws were not enforced, owing to neglect and incompetence by officials of the Crown Solicitor's Office and a lack of persistence by the Taxation Office.
He came to the nub of the problem here, I think, rather nicely when he said:

Whether the perpetrators of the 'bottom of the harbour' tax evasion schemes can still be prosecuted under the Crimes Act or common law on charges of conspiracy with intent to defraud the Commonwealth remains to be tested.

This is not, however, what the argument about retrospectivity is about. Such action under long established laws would be belated, not retrospective, prosecution of criminal offences. A criminal wrong does not become a right because of tardy law enforcement.
In that article Forell, of course, is not necessarily arguing for the creation of new offences.
In Chapter 10 of volume 2 of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Costigan said:

. . . It is . . . apparent the law enforcement agencies have not identified in any meaningful way the nature and extent of organised crime operating here. They have not taken any steps to suppress it. Indeed, in some of the agencies there is ignorance as to its existence.
He does not blame the people now working in these agencies. He continues that they:
. . . have shown an . . . earnest desire to enforce the laws . . . and a willingness to apply themselves far beyond the strict terms of their employment . . .

But he does detail the reasons why they have been unsuccessful, and they are matters of political will and of management. They are: Firstly, because of inadequate numbers of personnel and appropriate skills and capacity, secondly, inadequate equipment, reflecting nineteenth century attitudes and, thirdly, a lack of power to seize records, including bank accounts and tax records. These are reasons for a thorough overhaul of law enforcement agencies and also for the establishment of a permanent crimes commission with an attached prosecutors office to undertake prosecutions where these cannot properly by done by existing agencies. I advocate that without suggesting for one moment that the Government can use the establishment of a crimes commission to curtail or truncate Mr Costigan's inquiries. Mr Costigan has shown the way. We should not ignore his wisdom. It is clear that the tentacles of these operations have reached well into our political structure.

Let me conclude by making an appeal to the Government-I believe the Labor Party will agree with what I am about to say-that, if anyone requires further examples for the urgent need for public funding of political parties, surely these revelations and, as I understand, these revelations that are about to take place with particular reference to members and supporters of both the National Country Party and the Liberal Party, we need no other evidence to support it than what has come to light.

We have recently read of a fund raiser of the Liberal Party, a former chairman of the Sydney Stock Exchange, raising, in five weeks, something like $2m in Sydney to wipe off a Liberal party debt. I do not know where that money came from. No member of parliament knows. But somebody knows where it came from. I am not prepared to believe that none of it came from people who might have been involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. If someone heavily involved in a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme did make a substantial contribution-$500,000 or whatever-I need only to state the kind of pressure that individual can exert on senior members of the Liberal and National Country Parties when they are framing this legislation. I believe that, if any example were required for the urgent need of public funding of political parties to get these creatures out of the way and to clean up this political system, this is it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this urgency motion which has been raised by the Australian Labor Party. Senator Chipp has said that he looks forward to the vote. I believe that every honourable senator in this chamber from all parties will unequivocally support this urgency motion because the terms of it are such that I believe that every true Australian should support it . I ask honourable senators to look at the wording very carefully. It begins with:

SPEECH.PARA: I know we often think that we are talking of semantics when we talk about the terms 'evasion' and 'avoidance', but there is no doubt about it in this case. The emphasis is on the word 'evasion'. It concerns the understatement of income, the overstatement of expenses and all these sorts of things, including artificial schemes, contrivances, et cetera. Everything that is envisaged in both the original and amended section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act are conjured up in this term. There is no doubt that the full force of the law has to be brought to bear upon those people who sold company shares at prices which made no allowance for the companies' contingent liability. That effectively isolates certain types of transactions. I think this is important.
The motion ends with the words:
. . . and the need for the Senate to unequivocally support this action.

As I said, every true Australian must support this sort of motion. But why is the motion necessary? The Government has already indicated what it is going to do. It is true that we have not seen the actual wording of the legislation. I think that is a little unfortunate. Perhaps the Opposition parties believe that they have something to gain by pushing us forward because, after all, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) made it very clear on Budget night what he intended to do. Of course it is difficult to speak as to the exact application of the proposed legislation because we have not seen it. But we are told that the emphasis will be on fraud-where fraud is involved, there is no difficulty. Having established fraud, we are really seeking to collect the tax which resulted from that particular fraud. In other words, I believe we are seeking to introduce certain types of machinery provisions, not the taxing provisions. The fraud exists and the money is to be collected. We intend to introduce the appropriate machinery- type provisions to enable funds derived in a fraudulent manner to be recovered.

There has been so much hysteria in relation to this whole question of tax avoidance involving companies that a lot of very innocent people cannot sleep at night. In fact, people who have generally sold shares on the stock exchange are now wondering whether they will be liable for the payment of tax. Aged women who sold shares listed on the stock exchange, perhaps for the purpose of buying a carpet for their home, are now wondering whether this sort of transaction will be taxed. Of course it will not be taxed. But this is the sort of hysteria that has been generated as a result of a lot of ill-informed and mischievous reporting in this matter.

We then come to the question of shares in proprietary companies, particularly exempt proprietary companies. We have the situation of people who sold shares to other people ringing up the company secretary and saying: 'Is this the subject of a bottom-of-the-harbour-type scheme?' Of course such a transaction is not. Then we have the other situation which has occurred with a fair degree of frequency in my own State of Tasmania when mainland companies have bought out a number of existing operations. They have not bought the company as a whole; they have bought the assets and plant, they have taken over the debtors and creditors , and the tax liability has been set aside and met. The result is that after some time we are left with a shell of a company with no more than unappropriated profits represented by certain cash. Most of these companies have sat there for a year or two and the tax liability on the current year's profits has been met and paid and then along comes a promoter who offers a price and those shares are sold. It may be that further down the line there is some sort of distribution, but at that point there cannot be any liability so far as tax is concerned. In fact, such a practice is not covered by the motion before us. As I understand it , the Government's projected legislation is not intended to cover such a practice. In fact, I think we should note that the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union- the Costigan report-clearly distinguishes the two cases. I refer to paragraph 3. 119 on page 89 of the report, which states:

The statistics provided to me by the Taxation Office concern two types of application of schemes described in this report. The first concerns companies which have accumulated profits, but on which they have paid company tax. The purpose of the application of the scheme is to avoid the payment of tax on the distribution of those profits to the shareholders. It was this type of operation that the decision in Slutzkin concerned. It is not the type of case with which I am concerned in this Report.
It is not the type of case that is covered by the urgency motion we are debating today. The report at paragraph 3.120 states:

The second type of case is of a very different order. In these instances the company has accumulated profits during the year upon which company tax is payable (and upon which, on distribution, further tax may be payable by the beneficiaries of the distribution). Some promoters describe this as a 'current year profits' case; the Taxation Office describes it as a ''pre-tax profit strip ''.
They are the cases that are covered by the Government's intended legislation. They are the cases that are covered by this urgency motion. The report further states:
In these cases the object is to avoid the payment of the company tax properly levied upon the company by leaving only the shell of the company with no assets to pay the tax.

It is interesting to look at the statistics and this is the reason why the Government is taking action. In 1973, 27 companies engaged in this activity. In 1980 the number was 1,412. It grieves me greatly when I hear members of the Opposition say that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) stands accused, that he watched over tax evasion schemes. This sort of language implies connivance or an indifference. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of the measures that have been undertaken by the Treasurer from 1 July 1977 to the current date to prove to those people who read what has been said in this debate that measures have been taken and to put an end to this falsehood that the Treasurer has merely stood by and watched.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is wrong to say that the Treasurer has purported to be tough; he has been tough. Tough measures have been taken, particularly measures such as the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act under which promoters of a scheme can be sentenced to five years' goal or fined $50,000. If anything is lacking in the discussion today it is the failure to attack the promoters of these sorts of schemes. It is true that the schemes will be attacked under the Crimes (Taxation Offences Act) 1980. But I believe that we should be a lot harder on these promoters when we are framing proposed legislation because they are the people who sought to make ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayers pay more than they would otherwise have to pay. It is our Government's resolve to make sure that there is equity, vertical and horizontal, so far as taxation law is concerned. However, we have to be careful in respect of a number of innocent types of situations.

SPEECH.PARA: If we review a number of files which deal with the above matters we find that at the point of sale there is usually provision for the payment of 46c in the dollar on the current year's profits. What about a situation in which the tax on these profits has been deducted by the purchaser and has been clearly identified as such in the sale documents? In some cases the primary tax payable may be provided for and deducted and in some cases it may be actually set aside and paid into a special bank account by the purchaser at the point of purchase. The vendor shareholders have acted honourably and done the right thing. They put the money into a special bank account and there was no intention to defraud. How are we going to deal with situations in which the vendor actually takes the money? Are we going to come back and attack the vendor shareholders for the tax that they set aside, put into a special bank account and handed over to the purchaser of the company because the tax liability from the Taxation Office has not yet been determined and therefore was the responsibility of the new owners? I believe that in framing the legislation we will have to be very careful that we attack only those vendors involved in fraud. In the case I have mentioned, the vendors did the right thing. They calculated the tax, they set money aside, they put it in a special bank account and it was also deducted from the purchase price.

I think it is unfortunate that we have not had enough discussion about how we will go about dealing with this whole scheme. There has been a lot of innuendo and hysteria. Many loose words have been spoken. But what we must emphasise is that where there is fraud involved in the transactions-there was always fraud- there are offences against both the companies legislation and the crimes legislation. As Senator Rae said, there are offences against revised section 260 . All these things do not create a retrospective offence. We are not seeking to make illegal something which was legal at the time of execution. We are simply seeking to recoup the proceeds of the fraud. The emphasis is on the fraud from those who benefited from that fraud.

What we also have to do is to attack more savagely the promoters. Senator Rae made a very good point about attacking those involved in tax avoidance schemes by cancelling their registration on the Tax Agents Registration Board. I believe we may even have to go further because one of the problems that the Treasurer faced was section 16 of the secrecy provisions. Maybe we will have to open up and widen certain of the secrecy provisions to assist the Treasurer to follow through these tax avoidance schemes. I believe that a lot of the criminals involved in this have tried to confuse and muddy the waters. That is unfortunate . What we have to try to do, and what I hope I have done, is clarify the position so that innocent people are not indicted along with those who are criminally involved.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I present a report on tenure of academics, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate referred the question of tenure for academics to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts almost 12 months ago. We have comprehensively investigated this matter, having received 150 submissions from all parts of Australia and held public hearings involving more than 70 witnesses . These included, of course, people from individual universities and colleges of advanced education, the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, the Australian Conference of Principals of Colleges of Advanced Education, the Tertiary Education Commission, staff associations and many individual Australians.

General observation of the higher education sectors shows that since the mid- 1970s tertiary institutions have experienced little growth. With student participation rates levelling off and only small real growth in financial resources, there has been a dramatic collapse in the numbers of new academic appointment opportunities. Whilst in the period of expansion staff turnover for new appointments had been 10 per cent and more and whilst a normal turnover would be 5 per cent, we have found that in recent years the actual opportunities for new appointments have fallen to 1 per cent in both universities and colleges . This has very serious consequences.

Currently, so few new academic appointments are available that career prospects for younger academics are quite uncertain and initial entry is not at all promising. The low rate of academic staff turnover is analysed carefully in chapter 3 of the report. This analysis clearly indicates the threatening prospect of academic stagnation within some institutions. Because of the degree of autonomy of tertiary institutions and their diversity in nature and operation , and because the problems they are facing are complex and apparently entrenched , the solution of these problems has tended to be relegated to an administrative and political no-man's land. This report has taken on the task of identifying and clarifying these problems, as well as suggesting changes designed to stimulate progress in Australia's universities and colleges of advanced education.

The suggested changes to the tenure system in no way deny the advantages of tenure, which the Committee sees as substantial. Tenure provides the security of employment and remuneration which allows the freedom of inquiry essential to academic work in our democracy. However, the tenure system impacts significantly on the academic staff structures of institutions and the present system has limited and inhibited institutional flexibility.

The Committee's inquiry revealed that the legal position of tenure is uncertain and there is great diversity among institutions in appointment and dismissal procedures. The evidence showed that tenure relies more on convention than on contractual right. The Committee has identified the specific need for more unified and coherent conditions of service for tenured academic staff. The general thrust of the Committee's report and recommendations, therefore, is not to dismantle the tenure concept but to modify and improve its operation for present day circumstances. I believe that the Committee has responsibly tempered the utilitarian call by many for the abolition of tenure in order to gain an increase in staffing and financial flexibility, by recommending a more responsive and accountable tenure system. The report seeks to strengthen the advantages of tenure while at the same time ensuring that there are in operation effective program procedures which overcome the tenure system's principal problems.

I now highlight some of the specific recommendations in the report. The selection and appointment of an academic to a post which holds the expectation of tenure requires the most careful appointment procedures. The earlier prevalent practice of appointment being undertaken alone by 'god-professors' is a thing of the past. International advertisement for most tenurial posts, combined with the selection processes of broadly-based selection committees, ensures a thorough and sound assessment before appointments are made. The Committee commends these current practices and has further recommended the wider international advertising of academic vacancies, particularly in the colleges of advanced education. Currently, before tenure is confirmed an academic must successfully undertake a probationary period of service. At present, this period of probation varies greatly between institutions. For the reasons outlined in chapter 4 of the report, the Committee has recommended that the period of probation for the first appointment to a lectureship should be a minimum of three years and preferably five years.

A central issue in this inquiry was the need for institutions to achieve a greater degree of financial and staffing flexibility. Currently, the proportion of tenured staff in these institutions is tending to increase-for many beyond 90 per cent-and is hampering flexibility. It causes rigidity and frustrates new teaching and research initiatives, and it can lock up resources from constructive change and deny new and invigorating appointments. To overcome this problem without threatening the sound concept and operation of the tenure system , the Committee has recommended that the proportion of academics at the level of lecturer and above who are tenured should not in any circumstances exceed 90 per cent of the total full time equivalent number of lecturers and above in universities, and Lecturer Level II and above in colleges.

Tenure should not be, or be seen to be, a protection against incompetence or inefficiency. Tenure should be conditional upon an academic satisfactorily performing the duties and responsibilities expected by that academic's university or college. To give effect to this concept, the Committee has recommended, subject to certain necessary safeguards, that academics should individually participate in annual consultations and periodic reviews of their work. Where it is found that performance is inadequate, provision should be made for the termination of the academic's appointment. The Committee also believes that other provisions for the termination of an academic's employment should include serious misconduct, serious incapacity to perform academic duties by reason of physical or mental illness and financial exigency. Universities and colleges should therefore examine their statutory powers so that where necessary they can be amended or for the most part just put into practice to ensure that institutions have sufficient power to terminate appointments on these grounds.

I now turn to the terms of appointment of tutors. Under present financial and staff constraints, the career prospects and employment opportunities for tutors are contracting more than for other academic staff. The Committee is in no doubt as to the importance of tutors and the tutorial system in higher education institutions. Nevertheless the Committee agrees with the arguments of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission that tutorial staff are separate and distinct from career academic staff whether lecturers, senior lecturers, readers or professors. There should be no expectation that tutors are apprentice lecturers or that they should by right expect to progress from tutorship to lectureship. The Committee believes that tutor positions are, with some exceptions, short term appointments which give graduates the opportunity to assist in undergraduate teaching while acquiring a post-graduate qualification. Thus the Committee believes that tenure should not be extended to tutors. The Committee has concluded that only a specified minority of senior tutors should retain tenure and then only where sound advantages are defined. However the Committee was disturbed to uncover a degree of exploitation of tutors by tenured members of faculties, departments and, to some extent, institutions. The Committee views this with concern and has made a number of recommendations designed to lessen tutors' sense of insecurity and protect them from this exploitation.

I also draw the Senate's attention to the Committee's recommendation relating to superannuation. The Committee has recommended that every encouragement should be given to the establishment of a comprehensive, portable superannuation scheme for academics in higher education. This would not only ease the present financial burden on institutions but also encourage movement and interchange of academics between institutions. Such a proposal would help rejuvenate both institution and academic alike and would be a welcome innovation in the higher education sector.

I wish to conclude my remarks by reference to the academic staff distributions and age profiles described in chapter 3 of the report. Corrective measures still need to be taken to overcome the distortion in the academic age profile brought about by the years of rapid expansion of tertiary education being followed by cessation of growth. This distortion will increasingly become an indigestible problem for higher education institutions and, without corrective action, will reappear, on the reverse cycle, in a more intense fashion by the turn of the century. Unless managers of tertiary institutions, professional tertiary education bodies and individual academics recognise the consequences of this distortion, the existence of the institutions and the concept of tenure of employment may well be challenged. A healthy college and university system is a prerequisite for the existence and operation of the tenure concept. Institutions in these systems must solve their problems now, otherwise tenure may become, for that reason alone, seriously undermined.

The Committee's 39 recommendations seek to provide a realistic and comprehensive set of reforms which together should achieve sound and accountable arrangements for tenure and achieve an essential margin of flexibility for higher education institutions. The Committee urges the implementation of these recommendations in the careful manner set out in the report and so looks toward the enhanced well-being of teaching, research and scholarship in the universities and colleges of Australia. This is a unanimous report and, we believe, a sound report. The members of the Committee join me in thanking our staff, whose professional work in assisting this inquiry lived up to the highest standards of the Senate. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: I present for the information of honourable senators the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission containing its funding recommendations for the calendar year 1983. This report is in response to the Government's policy and financial guidelines on assistance for schools in the States and the Northern Territory. Honourable senators will recall that in the guidelines which I presented in the Senate on 17 August, the Government provided over $1,240m for all schools in 1983, a real increase of 3.9 per cent over the 1982 level. This allocation represents a continuation and an extension of the Commonwealth's commitment to all schools, whether government or non-government. Included in the guidelines allocation for 1983 are: A real increase in general recurrent grants for government schools to help overcome the financial difficulties facing government school systems, as reported by the Commission, additional general recurrent grants for Group 3 non-government schools, those with the lowest recurrent resources, to discharge the Government's commitment to raise these grants to 40 per cent of average government schools standard costs, maintenance of the base capital programs for both government and non-government schools, and additional grants for severely handicapped children and newly arrived migrant and refugee students. The Government also agreed to extend access to special education programs to children of below school age.

The Commission reports that there has been some public comment, both critical and supportive, on its overall funding recommendations and the Government's guidelines decisions. Much of the criticism has overlooked the relative roles and responsibilities of Commonwealth and State governments in the funding of government and non-government schools and that the Commonwealth is committed to ensuring high standards of operation in both sectors. In particular, mention is rarely made of the fact that, in real terms, more has been allocated for the total recurrent support of government schools by my Government last year, this year and next year than in the last year-1976-funded by the Labor Government, notwithstanding the decline in enrolments and the continued growth in State expenditure on government schools in that period.

The Commonwealth's support of non-government schools is a separate issue based on equity. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I would like to make some comments on behalf of the Opposition on the reports that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has just presented to the Senate. Firstly, with regard to the Schools Commission report it is very clear that what has happened over a number of years now of Fraser Government administration of the Schools Commission is that the independence of the Schools Commission, its original raison d'etre, has been eroded very seriously. The Schools Commission has now become so locked into the processes imposed on it by government that it is no longer able to distinguish between which of its recommendations are independent advice to the Government and which are the results of government directive. The current report appears to be devoted almost entirely to dividing up the funds in the way which the Government has decided in its guidelines and is virtually devoid of advice as to the appropriateness of those allocations or how they relate to the real needs of children in Australian schools. This incestuous relationship between the Schools Commission and the Government destroys the independence of the Schools Commission and deprives those interested in Australian schools of information and analysis to which they are entitled.

The nearest the Schools Commission comes to disagreeing with Government policies occurs when it expresses its regret at the discriminatory treatment meted out to government schools in the matter of cost supplementation. The outrageous decision of the Government to supplement fully its grants to non- government schools but to supplement only to the extent of two-thirds its grants to government schools was condemned by the Australian Labor Party when it was announced in June. We would have expected the Schools Commission to express a view forcefully and to explain the financial consequences of this unjustifiable decision.

A further example of the timidity of the Schools Commission occurs over its reference to what it calls the apparent re-emergence of the State aid debate. That the State aid debate is re-emerging strongly in the community is hardly news to the Government or, for that matter, to the public. Obliquely, the Schools Commission appears to be saying that in previous reports it put recommendations directed at achieving a proper balance in Commonwealth funding. The failure of the Government to act on its recommendations is the basis of the growing conflict over the Commonwealth's role in school funding. This is absolutely correct, of course. The Government has no policy in relation to funding the needs of government schools. The Schools Commission report shows that the share of Commonwealth funds going to government schools has declined from 61.9 per cent in 1976 to 47.2 per cent in 1982. This is a disastrous trend and it should be no surprise to the Government that those who choose government schools are deeply resentful of the policies long followed by the Fraser Government.

Nowhere in any Government statement does one find any acknowledgement of the needs of government schools for additional support. Instead, the Minister is intending to rest on the far from impressive statistic that he has at least restored funding to government schools to its 1976 level. That, of course, ignores the fact that the 1976 level of funding was only part way through a program of resources of improvement set in train by the Labor Government in 1974 and 1975 and not carried through by the Fraser Government. It also ignores the multiplication of problems and challenges which schools have had to face since 1976 resulting from increasing poverty, changing family structures, youth unemployment and so on, all mainly the result of the Fraser Government's economic strategies. While the Government refuses to adopt any targets for resource improvements in government schools it is axiomatic that its funding formula will continue to operate so as to disadvantage government schools and the state aid debate will grow in deafening intensity.

I should make it quite clear that the Labor Party does not wish to see a divisive state aid debate growing and becoming more intense. But we predict that this will be an inevitable result of the discriminatory attitude of the Government to government schools and of the Government's refusal to acknowledge the needs of government schools. In my electorate the state aid debate has been provoked by the decision of the Government to fund a number of new independent schools and, in particular, a third grammar school in the Belconnen area. It will be the third grammar school for the entire Australian Capital Territory. It is understandable that this decision has provoked a great deal of resentment amongst the parents of those children who are attending government schools in need or non-government schools in need. At a time of shrinking resources and, indeed, declining enrolments in a number of areas of Canberra the decision to fund a new school which seems to offer nothing particular in the way of curriculum that could not be offered in any of the existing schools and which is not being established to meet any additional need is a provocative decision indeed. I am sure that this is an example that could be repeated many times throughout Australia. In concluding my remarks on that report, I would like to repeat the regret of the Opposition that the independence of the Schools Commission and its ability to give objective advice on the needs in education have been so seriously eroded.

I turn now to the Tertiary Education Commission report. I point out that the major defects in this report concern the failure of the Government to compensate institutions for salary and wage increases. The Government did attempt to predict these increases and to include sufficient funds to cover the estimated cost of the increases but the estimates were faulty. Most universities and colleges of advanced education have indicated that they lack the ability to meet the recent increases awarded by the Academic Salaries Tribunal. However, the increases must be paid. There are two consequences of that. The first is that the quality of teaching and research in the universities and CAEs will decline and jobs will be lost. Of course, both of those things will lead to a third consequence, which is that students will have available to them fewer and poorer courses.

It is of great concern to us that at a time of massive unemployment, at a time of massive structural unemployment, at a time when the economy needs all the skills and expertise that can be mustered throughout our community, the Government seems to be intent on preventing people from gaining appropriate skills in CAEs and universities. We hope that the Government will review its decision with regard to the wage and salary supplementation costs of the tertiary sector.
