TALK.START.PARA: — The statement that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has put down on the report of the Schools Commission for 1983 unfortunately, I think, as Senator Ryan has already pointed out, is illustrative of recent reports. These reports used to be looked forward to as a major input into the educational debate regarding schools in this country. I think the major problem with this particular report is that the Commission spends an enormous amount of time on the distribution of funds and very little time on the reasons behind its decisions and projections forward.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 3 of the Minister's statement the point is made that there is an endorsement of the Commission's intention to implement fully the Government's previous decision to give consideration to income as well as expenditure in the assessment of non-government schools subsidy categories. Certainly the Australian Democrats welcome that extension. We believe it is a matter of concern that such an off-hand, as it were, comment has been made about something which is causing the community an enormous amount of concern, that is, growing division and acrimony because of the debate about the funding of government and non-government schools and the distribution of funds between those schools. I would hope, in line with the comments that I have made for some considerable time now, that the Commonwealth Government would give a lead in this area and would raise for national debate what it sees as being a way out of a continuing and destructive debate in the community. Whereas up to five, even three years ago, there was some considerable agreement on the part of both government and non-government schools as to where they might be going and the juxtaposition between the required funds for each group, we now have total disagreement, to the point where we have the major teachers union having as its policy, announced earlier this year, no funds for government schools. That is obviously a position which is totally unacceptable to all political parties in Australia but one which is, I think, understandable in light of that union's endeavour to have a reasonable debate about what might be the best way of accommodating two major schooling institutions within this country.

I believe that the Minister ought, in this statement, to have alluded to those parts of the Commission's report, brief though they were, in which this item was raised and given some lead as to the Government's thinking or where this thinking may have been derailed. I am sure that the Minister himself, in the time that he has been in this portfolio, has already run up against this problem time and time again, if not every day. We need some imaginative responses from this Government. I have called repeatedly for a peak conference of the various groups concerned to see whether at round table discussion those various groups could come to some modus vivendi. They certainly would not come to an agreement on all matters, and that is not to be thought likely. The contenders for both the government and non-government schools systems would be putting, at their very basis, diametrically opposed propositions. But I do believe that there are some areas in which agreement could be reached.

May I raise one area that concerns me, that is, the notion of entrances and exits from non-government schools. I do not believe that non-government schools are implacably opposed to controls over that area similar to those that operate in government schools. It is just not a matter of justice that one school system , the government school system, should have imposed on it an obligation to accept every child within the community who presents himself to that school, and another schooling system, almost equally funded now, certainly in the recurrent area by taxpayers' money, should be without that particular obligation. I believe that the entrances to schools ought to be on a par. I have expressed this view at meetings with representatives of non-government schools. While they said that they would not agree to it straight off, in continuing discussions they did not express any opposition in principle to that proposal. I believe that may be one step towards alleviating some of the tensions that exist so that government schools do not have to carry, as many of them do, rejects from the non-government school system. These are students whom the non-government school system found too hard or too difficult to teach or who had some disadvantage, social or otherwise, so that they were jettisoned out of that school system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where should they go if the private schools won't have them?

—I am saying they are jettisoned out of the private school system and they present themselves to the government school system and the government schools have to take them in under their legal obligation. The point I am making is that it may be one step forward if we look at a similar regulation governing the entrance to non-government and government schools. I do not think it would be beyond the capacity of the Federal Government, which has the responsibility for the majority of funding to non-government schools, to discuss that with the non-government schools and to come to some arrangement in relation to it. If we had these types of arrangements in regard to entrances to various schools then similar controls would have to be exercised also on exits from non-government and government schools alike. I believe that some movement in that area or other areas, for example, a delineation of the responsibilities of the various systems in training teachers, would be an advantage. The government schools system currently picks up vastly in excess of its proportion or its equitable number, as it were, of inexperienced teachers. The first, second and third years in the teaching life of any teacher are concerned very much with learning on the job. The teachers are operating below par. That is not in any way an indictment on them; it is a fact that anybody going into a profession is not able to operate at the peak of that profession when entering it. The teachers are learning. Therefore, the schooling system-there may be an arithmetic judgment in relation to the student-teacher ratio-is not getting the same value out of its teachers as many of the private schools which pick up the cream of our teachers.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other aspects to this matter. I refer to the fact that by and large government schools look after the isolated children in this country. The costs of isolated or remote education are extraordinarily high when compared with urban education. Yet we have a straight arithmetical operation that does a disservice to the complexity of the education system. There are those and many more aspects which I hope the Government will look at. I hope that the Government will give some lead to derail what is becoming an increasingly deleterious debate on the distribution of funds between these two schooling systems.

I now turn to the statement made by the Minister on the Tertiary Education Commission report. I wish to refer to a couple of matters only. I believe the report is very disingenuous in some ways in its wording. The Government strongly supports the view of the Commission about Armidale. The Minister's statement agrees with the Commission in relation to the Bendigo College of Advanced Education and the Orange Agricultural College. The statement spends a great deal of time agreeing with the Commission. Quite frankly, in the real world of educational policy decision-making the original impetus for all of this came from the Government. The fact that the Commission is falling into line with the Government's guidelines and recommendations, as are included in the appendices to this report, hardly suggests that we now ought to have a statement from the Minister agreeing with the Commission. The Government, having got the Commission , under its guidelines, to agree with it then used the Commission as a substantiating argument for what is happening in relation to the amalgamations.

One point which worries me excessively is that the University of New England has not agreed to come into an amalgamation. It has made a judgment-a judgment which I believe most of the institutions which are forced into these shotgun marriages would have made-that the educational justification probably would be zero. The justification for these ideas came out of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. Indeed, it was an economic decision tarted up to look like an educational decision. The part of the Minister's statement with which I am concerned is as follows:
It is a matter of concern that the attitude of the University is threatening the continued funding of advanced education at Armidale.

I cannot imagine the universities seeking to do anything to threaten educational funding in Armidale. I am quite sure that the people of Armidale do not see the university as threatening the funding. I suggest that the people of the electorate which includes Armidale will be concerned to discover that, contrary to the comment in the Minister's statement, it is the Government which is threatening the continued funding of advanced education in Armidale. I am quite sure that next time the Minister goes back there he will receive a more heated reception than he had last time. The fact of the matter is that most of the amalgamations will save very little money. Educationally very little will be achieved. The types of things that the Government was seeking to do-if it was seeking to do very much in an educational sense-could have been achieved by a multicampus arrangement which most of the institutions had already instigated. I do not think that the forced imposition of a new idea on amalgamation has necessarily added to the educational output of those insitutions.

I now deal with technical and further education. The types of expenditure which the Government has made are very welcome, particularly those in relation to the development of new capital works. In that area I believe that the Government has had a very good record for some considerable time. However, the Government itself must now give close attention to the problems of technology in relation to TAFE colleges. By and large TAFE colleges must keep an extremely close link with industry. Industry is undergoing enormous changes in terms of computer technology and, in particular, changes in the area of metalwork. Many of the TAFE institutions, owing to the lack of funds in terms of equipment grants, do not have within them the machinery to train students to use in industry. That is a continuing problem. It is a problem which TAFE institutions probably feel much more than most because of the rapid technological changes which occur. I do not necessarily believe that one needs to equip TAFE colleges with all types of machinery, but additional funds may be needed to establish a closer work- educational link with the industries so that we do not need to have a duplication of resources but will be able partly to fund, as it were, the employment of those machines in industry in return for their use by TAFE students. I do not think it is beyond the wit of the TAFE colleges to do that but obviously there would need to be a supporting funding arrangement.

The other item to which I refer in relation to TAFE arises out of a similar problem regarding technological development. I refer to the necessity for staff to upgrade themselves in their own area of expertise. Some years ago we had an unholy attack concerning the study leave of academics working in various sectors . The attack was based on the assumption that these were glorified overseas trips that people took to enjoy themselves. It was almost impossible to be heard in that debate. If one were to do a cost-benefit analysis one would soon discover that Australia benefits enormously from an academic going overseas. By and large the academics pay for the trip almost entirely and they bring back new -found information and understanding. That is a cheap way-in fact, it is at somebody's expense-for Australia to get hold of the latest developments that occur outside this country.

Likewise, in terms of TAFE, this does not occur once every seven years. It may occur seven times in one year and not at all in the next six years. There needs to be a much more flexible arrangement in relation to continuing the upgrading of staff understanding in the TAFE area. I believe that insufficient attention has been given by the report, the Technical and Further Education Council and the Government's announcements to the growing problem of the technological revolution as it relates to the TAFE sector. I would not like my critical remarks to be taken as an indication that the Government has not done a great deal in this area, as it should, and in the types of developments in which it has engaged. The fact is that the Government has at least maintained, or slightly increased, in real terms the funding to the various levels in the tertiary sector and it ought to be applauded, particularly in view of the types of cuts that have been made in other areas.

I merely repeat the point I have reiterated many times on behalf of the Australian Democrats: We see the education sector not as an area that ought to be counted in terms of costs but rather an area which must always be looked at in terms of its investment. By funding to a greater extent than we are now doing we can hope to meet the types of challenges that the technical revolution is bringing upon us. To do anything-including the aborted scheme to implement fees- which would in any way damage the prospects of getting every possible student who is academically qualified to engage in any tertiary education we are able to provide and which would prevent any one of those students from continuing would be a loss to the country and a loss to our development.

I hope that the next time we debate a report from an education commission we will get some of the things Senator Ryan spoke about; that, is, a bit more rigorous and gutsy presentation from the Commissions as to what they see are the problems of education in this country. In terms of its policy response the Government can then say: 'We cannot meet all of those, but this is what we can do'. At least the Commissions will be pushing the Government, as is their role. They ought to be pushing the Government, because of their expertise, about where we should be going. They are not bodies which should follow behind the policy judgments that the Government gives. I am quite sure that the Minister, in his own quiet moments, would not mind having a much more rigorous and gutsy approach from the commissions concerning the problems of education in this country. At least when he gets into a debate he will have something to react to rather than the bland presentations we have had in these two reports.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT DECISIONS ON RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY INTO MANAGEMENT EDUCATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will remember that on 27 May this year I tabled the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Management Education, the document known as the Ralph report from the name of its distinguished chairman. The Ralph inquiry had arisen , it will be recalled, from the Government's consideration of a recommendation contained in the report presented by the Study Group on Structural Adjustment, known as the Crawford report. Along with the reports from two other broad inquiries commissioned by this Government, the Williams and Myers reports, the Crawford report contributed towards stimulating a climate of community thinking in which more precise action for the future of management education became possible. Working on the best possible advice obtainable in the Commonwealth in the related fields of education and training, technological change, and issues of policies and structural adjustments for Australian industry, the Government has in this manner set out on a course of constructive concern for the future of technological and business studies in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: When I tabled the Ralph report, I therefore issued at the same time a statement seeking wide-ranging public comment on the content of the report. In view of the significant studies that had been commissioned by the Government since late in the 1970s, and in view of the deep interest which they had aroused in all sections of the educational, commercial, and industrial communities, it is not surprising that the report's presentation drew the volume of response for which we had hoped.

Representations about the report have been made directly to my office, and to various sectors of the Commonwealth Education portfolio. They have come not solely from the central administration of universities and colleges of advanced education, from departments and individual lecturers within institutions, from education authorities in the States, from State governments themselves, and from the business community, but also from students who have a personal stake in the future of management education courses.

The advice given to me about the report by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has also been tabled today as an appendix to volume 3 of the Commission's report for the 1982-84 triennium. The advice given there makes clear the reasons for the width and depth of this reaction to the report. Fundamental issues of academic standards, of institutional autonomy, of rationalisation of expensive resources, and of access to courses in management education at various levels, were addressed there. Implementation of decisions about these kinds of issues requires, in the Government's view, the most careful consultation with the implementing bodies involved. The results of our deliberations are, therefore, arranged around this theme of concern.

Honourable senators will observe that the Commission supports substantially the recommendations contained in the report, with some reservations, and that it makes positive suggestions for implementing the report's objectives. The major recommendations refer to the rationalisation of programs of management education offered by institutions of higher education, the establishment of a second graduate management school under special, ear-marked funding arrangements, the concentration of part time Master of Business Administration studies in one management school in each mainland State, the provision by other tertiary institutions of a variety of programs encouraging wider access to management education through formal and informal courses, and the creation of an Australian foundation for management development.

Here it will be appreciated that the overriding interest of those responsible for the Ralph report has been to find methods to attain and maintain the highest possible quality of education for those who will be the nation's middle-level and senior business managers. The report's central objective has been to raise this quality of business management education at all levels, not solely on the plane of courses leading to the degree of Master of Business Administration, but also at other levels of award courses, and also in the non-award sector. The basic argument of the report is that it is better to achieve, by concentration of effort, high-quality MBAs and post-graduate diplomas rather than MBAs of varying standards. To do otherwise would both devalue these degrees, and disadvantage students, managers, and the community generally.

The report, therefore, asserts that adequate numbers of well-qualified staff are required to provide better courses to meet the varied needs of the business community. It lays particular emphasis on the future of higher education in business management. It recommends the establishment, under special funding, of a second graduate school of management at the University of Melbourne, offering substantially full time MBA and Ph.D. courses, and providing leadership through research. This school would complement the Australian Graduate School of Management at the University of New South Wales, and it is intended that these two would be the only institutions offering full time programs towards the degrees of Master of Business Administration.

The Government has accepted the recommendation to establish in 1983 a second graduate school of management with a national role at the University of Melbourne. This will entail provision of up to $4m by the Commonwealth-in 1982 out-turn prices-towards the construction of a building for the school. The University and the business community will be expected to meet a significant part of the total cost. Commonwealth support for the project will also depend upon the University providing satisfactory responses to the requirements stipulated by the Committee of Inquiry and supported by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. Discussions on the establishment and management of the Melbourne school will be under the joint direction of the Chairman of the Committee of Inquiry, Mr J. T. Ralph, and the Secretary to my Department, the Department of Education, Mr K. N. Jones. This will be with a view to promoting the active co-operation and involvement of the Australian business community in the management and financing of the school. I shall then report to the Government as soon as possible on the arrangements proposed. Along with this provision, additional recurrent funds would be allocated under the CTEC programs , amounting to $200,000 in 1983 and $300,000 in 1984, also in 1982 out-turn prices. The Commission believes that this funding will suffice to enable the University to appoint additional staff, and to improve its support services, where necessary.
Grants towards the establishment of the second graduate school of management will be incorporated in States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) legislation, shortly to come before the Senate.

Honourable senators will have noted that the Ralph report recommended limitation of part-time MBA programs to one institution in each mainland State, and that it named these institutions, all universities. The recommendations would also reduce the external MBA course offered by Deakin University to a post -graduate diploma, and would limit colleges of advanced education to offering, at the post-graduate level, diplomas in business administration. Honourable senators will be aware that some colleges of advanced education offer well- regarded MBA courses. The Government, therefore, agrees in principle with the desirability of rationalising programs of management education and of concentrating resources for part time MBA courses into one institution in each mainland State, but recognises that the Ralph Committee did not state the criteria used for differentiating between institutions. Nor did it provide an overall program to meet the varied needs in each State for access to different levels and forms of business administration courses.

In this connection, there has been considerable criticism by institutions which would be affected adversely by the proposed limitations on the courses which they would continue to offer. State governments have expressed similar concern. Accordingly, the Government agrees with the proposal by the Commission to seek submissions from State authorities and institutions on how best to achieve the rationalisation of courses and the concentration of resources envisaged by the Committee of Inquiry. It has decided to request the Commission to report by March 1983 on the best means to achieve this in each State.

The Ralph report also proposes that an Australian Foundation for Management Development should be established to provide a continuing overview of management education, to establish standards, and possibly to accredit courses in management education. It would perform the functions which are undertaken by professional bodies in other fields. A foundation of this kind should make a significant contribution towards advancing management education, and the Government agrees that its establishment is a vital ingredient in improving business administration. It, therefore, proposes that the business community be invited to establish and provide continuing financial support for an Australian Foundation for Management Development, with $50,000 being provided by the Commonwealth in each of the years 1983 and 1984 to assist establishment.

As a means of improving the qualifications of academic staff working in the field of management education and of encouraging research by highly qualified students, the Ralph Committee has recommended that scholarship and teaching assistantships should be provided. I shall submit to the Government proposals to be considered in the context of the 1983 Budget. This would allow for measures to operate on behalf of staff and students from 1984 onwards.

It must be said that the Ralph report gave limited consideration to the educational needs of small business. The Government is convinced that this is an important area which requires further study. It will, therefore, ask the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to consult with the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Industry and Commerce to report on business management programs in tertiary education to meet the needs of small business.

The remainder of the 45 recommendations contained in the Ralph report largely concern matters which are the prime responsibility of State authorities and institutions and are not matters appropriate to Commonwealth direction. I shall ask the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to seek to promote these recommendations.

It only remains to say that the Government and the Australian community are greatly indebted to the members of the Ralph Committee for the considerable and highly valued work which they have devoted to their surveys and deliberations and the compilation of their report. It was a difficult task to be undertaken by the first committee to report on national needs for management education since the Cyert Committee that was established in 1970. The concerns which the Ralph Committee was asked to address were disposed over a much wider range of reference than those of the Cyert Committee. The intervening decade has seen a vastly accelerated degree of change in the exigencies and long term problems that are being presented for solution by Australia's present and future business managers. The achievements of the Ralph Committee and the decisions which have now been taken by the Government represent one further step in the program which I have outlined for the enhancement of management education in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has just delivered to this Senate the Government's decisions on the recommendations in the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Management Education-the report of the Ralph Committee . I say at the outset that the Opposition does not argue with some of the main thrusts of that report. We accept that there is a need for post-graduate management training of the highest standard. We accept that there is a need for a rationalisation of resources. We accept that the proposed new course at Melbourne University which will complement the existing course at the University of New South Wales is a desirable development. We acknowledge that management education in Australia has been erratic and of a fairly low standard in the past with some notable exceptions such as the New South Wales course. I think, as far as the general public is concerned, one has to look only at the plight of business in Australia, at the mismanagement there is at so many levels in the private sector in Australia, to agree that we should be looking to the development of excellent post-graduate education in the area of business management.

However, having said that and having said that we do accept the proposed new course at Melbourne and the reasons for it, I must point out that the Opposition has a number of reservations about the report and the Government's reponse to it . In particular we find that the report has been too narrow in its recommendations and the Government's response has been equally narrow. Whilst we accept that there ought to be these two major courses, one in Sydney and one in Melbourne, and we acknowledge that each State would have one institution where a part time master of business administration course would be offered and other institutions would be able to offer courses at a lower level, we believe that the whole area of business management education has now become too restrictive. It seems to us that the Ralph Committee's approach has been overall an elitist one, that it has shown a preoccupation with the needs of top level management in the large corporations to the exclusion of other very important areas in the economy-for example, to the exclusion of middle-sized small business, which I think the Minister has acknowledged. Of course, the needs of the public sector and of public enterprises have not been adequately addressed in this report or in the Government's response.

One of the consequences of the implementation of the Government's decision that management courses in institutions other than the ones nominated should be ceased is that many people, many students, will lose access to management education. I am particularly concerned that students who have been availing themselves of part time courses such as the one at Deakin University will no longer have these courses available to them. Many people who are studying management on a part time basis simply cannot afford to take off a year to study full time in any university doing a higher degree.

I attract the Senate's attention to the particular needs of women with regard to management education. As honourable senators will be aware, because I and some of my colleagues have made this point a number of times, women are seriously under-represented in management in this country both in the public sector and in the private sector. Once we go beyond the middle level of management in the private sector or in the Commonwealth Public Service we find very few women indeed. I hope that is a source of concern for senators on both sides of the chamber. Women themselves have been attempting to address this disadvantage by undertaking part time courses in business administration. Many women currently working in corporations are seeking to overcome their past lack of access to promotion by availing themselves of part time courses. Many of those women simply will not be in a position to take off a year full time to undertake a post-graduate course or indeed may not yet be at the level where they would be able to gain entry to the post-graduate course at the University of New South Wales or the one now proposed at Melbourne University.

So, there is a whole range of needs of students-and I use women as one specific example-and of people working in management to have access to part time courses. We do not believe that range of needs is going to be met by the implementation of the recommendations of this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you understand that our response left open the choice of institution or institutions in each State?

—I understand that the Minister said that he would be calling for submissions from State bodies and so forth about how the recommendations are going to be implemented. It seems to us that there will be a narrowing down of courses available in this area. It is our view that that narrowing down will lead to a significant lack of access. I give the example of Deakin University which has a largely part time student body. I do not know what the Government has in mind for Deakin University. I presume that negotiations have to take place. But I think that the work that has been carried out at Deakin in this respect and the kinds of students who have been able to avail themselves of the course at Deakin exemplify the sort of broad range of management education courses which ought to be available and which we are concerned will no longer be available once this report and the Government's response are implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: We think that the whole question of people living in non-metropolitan Australia is not properly addressed in the recommendations. People will be seeking to pursue studies at regional institutions, colleges of advanced education and the like. While some courses may be offered at a diploma level, it seems that there will be a winding down of these courses. Of course, we cannot look at the particular recommendations with regard to management education in isolation. A few minutes ago the Minister presented to us the report of the Tertiary Education Commission and Senator Macklin and I have made some comments on the problems facing tertiary institutions in this country, on the extent to which courses are being restricted and staff is being restricted. Now we have a proposal for a new approach to management education which in itself is restrictive.

I am sure Senator Macklin will agree with me that management education is something that this economy certainly needs. But we do not think that the Government's response to the established need is adequate. We fear that the Master of Business Administration courses are increasingly going to be available only to those who work for large corporations and, of course, to those who are selected by those corporations to attend. That means that the whole access to the MBA courses will continue to be elitist and will be more elitist than in the past. People who have not been able to gain promotion through large corporations -as I have said, women form a very large group who have had difficulties in that respect-will simply not be in that top rung of executives who will be chosen by corporations to be given the benefit of a year's leave to go and study full time for an MBA. This restriction of access to these courses to such a narrow group of people will, I think, lead to intellectual inbreeding at a time when Australian business desperately needs to attract new talent and new ideas.

The Minister, in his remarks, acknowledged that the needs of small business have not been adequately addressed in this report. It is the view of the Opposition that the needs of small business have been almost entirely ignored by the Ralph Committee's report. I note that the Government has proposed further action in this respect but I should like to remind the Senate that small business is vitally important to Australia. Overall, it is one of the largest sources of employment in Australia. It is the backbone of our business community . It has been particularly hard hit by the economic strategies of the Fraser Government, by monetarism. It has crucial and urgent needs for improvement in the management skills. Yet, of course, these needs have not been taken up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mostly non-award, because they cannot spare the time.

—The Minister points out that people in small business will not be able to spare the time to do a full time course. Again, I think that reinforces my view and the view of the Opposition that we need available a wider range of courses in administration so that people running a small business will be able to avail themselves of the courses.

SPEECH.PARA: The other major defect in the report concerns the needs of the public sector with regard to management training. These needs have almost been ignored. I point out to the Senate that this is a matter of great concern to the public. The public has a huge amount of money invested in public corporations, such as Telecom Australia, Trans Australia Airlines, electricity commissions, Qantas Airways Ltd and health commissions. There is vast public investment in these enterprises and, of course, these enterprises are also extremely important to our society in a fundamental way because they are engaged in the delivery of basic services. The management of our large public corporations is a matter that should be of great concern to all of us. I think it has to be admitted that in these large public corporations there is evidence of a need for improved managerial skills. The kinds of courses which are now proposed by the Ralph Committee will not meet the needs of these corporations. In fact, in such huge public corporations as Telecom, there are very many employees who are just below middle level management, who need these courses available to them, who will not be eligible for the full time one-year MBA courses in Sydney and Melbourne but who would profit very much from a variety of courses. Given the Government's current approach, and indeed the approach it has pursued for the past seven years, towards staff ceilings and leave entitlements in the Public Service, many people working in public corporations would be able to pursue management education only if part time courses were available to them. I hope that the Government will take note of this. We recognise that the Government has a fundamental hostility to public enterprises but, while they exist, surely the Government should agree that they ought to be managed in the interests of the public, which after all has such a huge investment tied up in them.

On the question of existing courses the Minister has indicated that there will be further discussions and submissions. But it is the view of the Opposition that this response is not adequate. We believe that the question of uncertainty surrounding existing courses, which it seems are now to be wiped out, will be very confusing and very distressing to students and teachers of those courses. The matter is urgent. People cannot start a course this year without knowing whether it will continue next year. The insecurity and uncertainty surrounding existing courses that do not fit into the Ralph Committee's recommendations need to be addressed immediately and not left for many months of further discussion.

In conclusion, I point out, as I did at the outset, that the Opposition does not oppose the setting up of a new MBA course at Melbourne University. It does not oppose the rationalisation of these courses or the attempts to ensure that these courses are run at the highest possible level. In fact, we endorse all of those objectives. But we do oppose the narrowing of access to management education which this report implies. In our view the question of existing courses should be dealt with immediately and it is our hope that as many of them as possible will be able to continue so that a whole range of people-people in small business, women and people in non-metropolitan areas who will never be able to do a full year's MBA course at Sydney or Melbourne-will be able to improve their understanding of management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -One of the principles enunciated in the report of the Ralph Committee of Inquiry into Management Education reads:

SPEECH.PARA: the objective of a national pattern of management education must be to provide as many managers as possible with access to forms of management education best suited to them

One of the principal objections from the academic and business communities to the Ralph report was that it did not fulfil that injunction. I do not think that the Government's response has done that either. In saying that I do not think that the Government's response has done that, I point out that the person who obviously drafted the other ministerial statements and this one has adopted a rather nice style because when I read it first I thought: 'My goodness, why have they done that?', and then I read it again and discovered it was something else entirely. On the third reading I probably discovered what the intent was. The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), by way of interjection, pointed out in relation to regional schools, for example, that it looked as though there was an acceptance of the Ralph Committee's report, but on closer reading it may not be there. I am still not sure what the final intent is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is so horrendous for some institutions, an interim response and further work seem to be fairest in equity.

—I certainly agree with the Minister on that, but in relation to one particular institution I do not think there can be any equivocation. That is Deakin University. It is the only institution of its kind and therefore there could not be any problem, to quote the Minister, about 'the criteria used for differentiating between institutions'. I presume that Deakin is to be reduced to a post-graduate diploma.
—The options for a regional school could conceivably involve multi-campus options.

—It could but the point of Deakin is the external studies. If that be the case, I should like to address my remarks to the point that Deakin may be reduced to a post-graduate diploma course. The problem with that-I pointed it out before but I think it is worth reiterating-is that the Deakin external studies started after the Ralph Committee had been going. I do not really believe that the Ralph Committee had sufficient evidence to make the types of judgments that it made-certainly the rather harsh judgment of its being a rather unsatisfactory mode for an MBA degree. The reason I say that is that, interestingly enough, the Deakin model has been exported. It has been adopted in the United Kingdom and in the United States of America. In fact, it has been accepted in papers at various international conferences as a leader in its field in terms of external studies. It seems to me very odd that we are thinking of forgoing something which is extremely useful to a country of our type; that we should be going backwards in regard to a scheme which other countries that, in other aspects of management education are far ahead of us, have seen fit to adopt. It seems analogous to a problem that we have in many areas-when we get ahead we get cold feet and want to draw back. The Deakin mode ought to be given encouragement and a chance to operate. If it does not come good a judgment in that regard can be made in due course, not in the abortive way that is being discussed now.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, I am extremely worried about that aspect of external studies, linked with another on which the Minister, by way of interjection, made a similar point-I refer to the small business operation. I find it very odd that, although the Ralph Committee report, the Government and the Minister in his response, acknowledge that only limited consideration has been given this problem, we are seeking a reorganisation and, in many ways, dismantling of the structure of management education at the very time that the Government also proposes an investigation of that area. I say that because, after all, small business is the business sector of Australia-not just a business sector. We do not seem to realise that in this country. If we were talking about the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or some such operation we would all be concerned but when we talk about small business we seem to jettison the whole idea of its importance. But managers of small businesses are the very people about whom we need to be concerned because they are the employers of this country. As the Minister has quite rightly said, in almost every case they are not capable of entering upon full-time study. Therefore, they would not be attracted to the New South Wales or Victorian models. But they would seek alternative models, one of which would be external. Such a course would be extremely beneficial to them, particularly if it were linked to some kind of executive weekend model, as has become current in the South African business school, which has an international reputation in that area.

If one looks closely at the needs of small business managers one will be reinforced in one's opinion that the Deakin model ought to be retained as part of the development in that area, as part of one of the innovations or modes by which the objective of the Ralph inquiry might be fulfilled; namely, that as many managers as possible should have access to forms of management education that is best suited to them. I do not think that the Minister's response was antithetical to what I have said. I hope that we will not lose an innovation from which Australia is now gaining some international repute.

The establishment of the second school at Melbourne would, I believe, be accepted by most people. Some of the funding issues may be of concern, certainly to Melbourne University, but in such an area as this I believe priorities have to be set by the university itself. Therefore, if it wishes to be a part of this scheme it would have to rationalise its own priorities. I believe that is a reasonable imposition to place upon it. I am concerned about one comment in the Minister's report which deals with the Australian Foundation for Management Development. I refer to the possible accrediting of courses in management. If that were done along the lines taken by other professional bodies I would certainly not have any objection to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what was in my mind.

—In that case, I have no objection. I was about to raise the point that if we were to have any interference with university autonomy it would be a bad move. If it were merely along the lines presently followed by, for example, doctors and accountants in stating their requirements, it would be perfectly acceptable to the universities and I believe management also. I raise another issue to which the Government has not, by and large, addressed itself. At the end of his remarks the Minister said that the majority of the remaining recommendations were the responsibility of other areas. I am not sure that one recommendation falls into that category, yet the Minister did not comment on it. I refer to the Ralph recommendation that no new MBA courses be approved before the end of 1993. I am concerned because it seems that if the Government does not comment on that it may be accepted as being operational. I hope that that is not the case, simply because I think that such arbitrary designations are not very useful in education. In 1973 the concept one had of the future world was a lot different from present actuality. I believe the arbitrary cutting off of reasonable development within various institutions is the sort of thing that institutions ought to be doing themselves, and coming forward with proposals on when an institution makes a proposal. It seems to me that is the appropriate time for a response as to whether or not it will be accepted. But I believe that institutions ought to have the ability to respond to what they perceive as community needs and to be able to present those points of view.

SPEECH.PARA: In that regard, Griffith University, an institution in my State, has planned three courses in this area. I do not know how it will fare. They are not intended to come to fruition this year or next but at an appropriate time the university would wish to bring them forward. I mention Griffith University because it was not the Queensland institution named in the report. In fact, that was the University of Queensland. Yet at Griffith University 30 members of staff teach business studies. The Ralph Committee report talked about the establishment of the national school and said that there would need to be a minimum of 25 staff members. The Griffith University was not named in the Ralph report-seemingly it will not even get a guernsey-yet it has a bigger staff than even the Ralph Committee report was proposing for the national school. I reiterate the point made by the Minister, that we need to look at what is happening before we make any move in this area. I hope that we do not have a very one-track view about this. It is possible and very reasonable to look at a range of innovations in terms of business management at the regional level. We could then provide not only undergraduate and part time courses but also, if the Government cannot come into it now, at a later point, post-graduate courses and definitely MBA courses. It would be a multi-campus operation which would disturb nobody. It could be operated by a regional school of management and people currently employed in the area could be employed with minimum disruption. With a rationalisation of the courses we may even promote better management education at the regional level. We will not promote that if we artificially cut off post- graduate study. I make that point because it is in the nature of institutions to be able to attract top quality people; that they can teach not only at the undergraduate level but also at the post-graduate level. If we do not allow research and teaching at the post-graduate level it will be almost impossible for regional schools to attract top quality people. Of necessity they will gravitate to the national school. Therefore, there would be an ultimate downgrading in management education in Australia. We have had in this country a convention in terms of our universities of treating them as being on a par. Certain universities excel in certain areas but, unlike other countries, we do not rate our universities. We try to bring them all up to a high level and to allow them to operate at a post-graduate level so that we can have diffuse education in the country. It would be a retrograde step and against the whole notion of how universities operate in the real world to say: 'You are not going into post-graduate studies or post-graduate research'. The Government responses leave open the prospect of our not closing off those innovative and exciting prospects that Australia has begun and, I hope, will continue.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (LOANS GUARANTEE AND SUBSIDY) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to provide for the giving of guarantees and subsidies by the Commonwealth in respect of certain loans made to eligible students.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the implementation of the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme which will be introduced from the beginning of 1983. The Bill provides for the Commonwealth to subsidise the interest charged by banks on approved loans and for the Commonwealth to give guarantees to banks that it will repay outstanding debts on approved loans within prescribed limits. The Bill also covers the eligibility conditions applying to loans.

The Tertiary Student Loans Scheme will enable full time tertiary students who are Australian citizens or permanent residents to borrow between $500 and $1,000 per annum from banks to help pay for their education and living expenses while studying. Students will be able to borrow up to $8,000 over the total period of their study.

Many full time students will be eligible for approved loans by virtue of their entitlement to benefits under various Commonwealth student assistance schemes. These schemes are: The Commonwealth Post-graduate Awards Scheme; the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, known as TEAS; the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme; and the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme. The Tertiary Student Loans Scheme will provide an additional source of support for eligible students receiving benefits under these schemes. Other full time students will qualify for loans providing they satisfy a simple means test, the details of which have already been announced in the Budget context. These details will be prescribed in regulations.

The Government has demonstrated its strong continuing support for student assistance schemes by its decision to increase substantially allowance levels and relax means tests for 1983. The loans scheme will provide another option for students. The interest rate to apply to loans will be the maximum rate permissible for advances by banks of less than $100,000-currently 14.5 per cent per annum-reduced by 5 percentage points by a Commonwealth subsidy. The Commonwealth will provide banks with guarantees amounting to $50m per annum on approved loans but the banks will be expected to take all reasonable steps to obtain repayments from defaulting borrowers before the Commonwealth honours guarantees.

The scheme will be administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education in conjunction with the banks and tertiary institutions, and the detailed terms and conditions for approved loans will be prescribed in regulations. Funds to meet payments by the Commonwealth of interest subsidies and the repayments of any defaulted loans will be provided for through the general appropriation legislation. For this financial year the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1982-83 provides $150,000 for these purposes. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity in whatever time is available to me to refer to a ministerial statement which the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) put down in another place last Thursday week. I will very briefly outline where it all started. On 25 February of this year, I asked a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs in this place, the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), as to some allegations pertaining to the embezzlement of a sum of money from the Tehran Embassy some years ago. On 5 March, I received a letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). The second paragraph of that letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: My Department is not aware of any embezzlement from the Australian Embassy in Tehran and a careful check of the post's financial transactions has not revealed any discrepancy.

Being a fairly reasonable sort of person-at that stage-I accepted to some extent what the Minister had said. However, on 24 March I received a second letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs wherein, in part, he said:
That is, the first letter of 5 March:
an officer of my Department has informed me that he has some information relevant to this matter.
I seek leave to have those two letters incorporated in Hansard.
DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS CANBERRA 5 March 1982
On 25 February you asked the Minister for Finance whether $35,000 had been embezzled from the Australian Embassy in Tehran and, if so, what action was taken on the matter.
My Department is not aware of any embezzlement from the Australian Embassy in Tehran and a careful check of the post's financial transactions has not revealed any discrepancy.

Let me add that I regard very seriously any suggestions of embezzlement or other financial impropriety. Should you be aware of any information which might not have come to departmental attention, I invite you to pass it on to me to facilitate any necessary investigations.

On 5 March 1982 I wrote to you, following your question without notice on 25 February to the Minister for Finance about whether there had been an embezzlement from the Australian Embassy in Tehran, to inform you that my Department was not aware of any embezzlement from that post and that a careful check of the post's financial transactions had not revealed any discrepancy.
