I shall inform you of the outcome as soon as possible.
Senator C. G. Primmer, Senator for Victoria, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600.

TALK.START.PARA: —At that stage, what had happened began to rankle me a little and caused me to wonder really what was going on in the Department of Foreign Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 15 of the Minister's statement which he put down last week he said:

All persons holding public office must be accountable for their actions. Any allegations or evidence of wrongdoing must be examined and action taken if it is warranted. If, moreover, any person believes that there have been wrongful acts committed, that person, and particularly an officer of the Public Service, has a clear duty to bring forward his or her concerns and, of course, must be entitled to protection against any possibility of vindictive action simply because allegations have been made.

Perhaps that is the main reason why this whole matter has somewhat rankled me. It has gone on for six or seven years. The people within the Department who have had the courage to stand on their convictions and their professional morality have been people who, in my view, have been victimised.

I turn again to the statement the Minister put down last Thursday week. In this statement, the Minister is, in my view, making a vain attempt to defend the indefensible-to protect two of his top officers from the exposure of their actions in the Tehran affair. In particular he attacked my efforts in the last six months to have these matters ventilated in the Parliament. During that time the very senior officers who provide Mr Street and the Government with its foreign affairs policy advice have worked unceasingly to convert chalk into cheese. By means of ministerial and permanent head pressure they have succeeded in fully implicating the Department of Finance and the Australian Federal Police in a disgraceful cover-up.

Officials paid to protect the taxpayer have, instead, worked to prevent the exposure of an ex-ambassador who has preyed on the public purse for more than two decades. Police officers, sworn to uphold the law, have bullied witnesses to withdraw their evidence against these corrupt Department of Foreign Affairs officers and have falsely reported that no evidence exists against them. At least three Ministers of this Government are knowingly involved in this cover-up which has even extended to withholding from the Parliament important documents relating to the matter. It is a sorry commentary on the state of affairs in Parliament today that most of these documents have had to find their way through the hands of the media who have provided them to the Opposition.

To avoid any misunderstanding, real or feigned, let me make it abundantly clear that I and the Opposition acknowledge that the vast majority of officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Finance and the Australian Federal Police are conscientious workers and upright citizens who are as strongly opposed as any of us are to corrupt activities of a small number of powerful senior personnel in collusion with each other and some Ministers to defeat the due processes of law.

It is instructive for us to consider briefly the recent history of this matter. As I explained in detail to the Senate on 29 April, the Parliament's involvement in this affair started on 25 February with my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As I stated earlier, Mr Street promptly telephoned me to say that his Department had assured him that there was no evidence whatsoever of embezzlement from the Embassy in Tehran. On 5 March, as I stated earlier, he sent me a letter prepared, I understand, by the Secretary to his Department, Mr Peter Henderson, which in part said:
My Department is not aware of any embezzlement from the Australian Embassy in Tehran and a careful check of the post's financial transactions has not revealed any discrepancy.

In purveying that letter, in my view Mr Street misled the Parliament. I present for inclusion in Hansard a Foreign Affairs document dated 22 March 1982 which provides evidence of Mr Henderson's handling of that matter. The author of that document was a Mr D. W. Witheford, the head of the Philippines-Thailand-Burma section of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I seek leave to have that document incorporated in Hansard.
Mr R. J. Smith, FAS Management and Foreign Service Division.
Since I have not heard from you since we spoke on 17 March, I am setting out a record of my various discussions with you and other staff.

2. After checking with Parliamentary Liaison (Calver) on 12 March, I telephoned the A/Head, Overseas and General Accounting Section (Brooks) to advise him that I had an input to make into the Foreign Minister's reply to Senator Primmer's question about embezzlement from the Embassy in Tehran. Brooks said that he thought the Minister's reply had already gone and that he would refer my inquiry to the A/AS Administrative Services Branch (Parkes). I therefore checked again with Parliamentary Liaison (Calver) to be told that the Department had not yet put a draft reply to the Minister. He said that my interest in the matter had been noted and that they would inform me if a draft letter came forward without my input. I indicated to both Brooks and Calver that there was every risk that a reply which did not include my input would lead to the Minister's misleading Parliament.

3. On 17 March, Parkes called me in to talk with him and Brooks. They sought to ascertain what my proposed input was, showing me the Minister's draft reply which stated that the Department was unaware of any embezzlement from the Embassy in Tehran. At my insistence, Parkes checked and confirmed that the Minister had signed the letter to Senator Primmer and dispatched it. I stated that the Minister had been misled and asked from whom had the submission to the Minister gone. Parkes sought to obfuscate, but finally agreed that it would have been from you or Mr Henderson. I therefore said that it now seemed that the Department had knowingly misled the Minister. I asked him (and subsequently you) for copies of the Minister's letter and the Department's covering submission to him (not provided). Parkes again claimed ignorance of any financial problem in Tehran and pressed me to give him all the information I had. I responded that his superiors were well aware of some of the details as had been his predecessor (Johns, now retired). I left him with the assertion that if the Department did not act promptly and honestly to undo the damage, I would feel obliged to seek to inform the Minister myself.

4. You subsequently came down to my office and, claiming that neither you nor your staff had any knowledge about embezzlement concerning the Embassy in Tehran , you pressed me to provide any information I had to you urgently. You reminded me that concealment of crime was, itself, a crime. Reminding you that you and other senior officers were well aware of serious irregularities involving a certain senior officer, both at Tehran and previously, I repeated what I had told you in our conversation of 18 November 1981 (a copy of the agreed record of which you hold) viz. that I feared everything would (again) be covered up and retribution (again) visited upon me and other officers involved.

5. Assuring you that I had no knowledge of how Senator Primmer had received his information, I explained to you that it was by no means a matter of indifference to me that the Department had wilfully sought to lock the Minister-and, indeed, the Parliament-into the false stance that nothing had happened in Tehran. I said that it was clear that you and another very senior officer, also apparently involved, had knowingly misled the Minister with the aim of protecting the malefactor. This was a reckless action since some of the facts were known to not a few Departmental officers, not to mention, apparently, Senator Primmer. I told you that I thought urgent steps should be taken to undo the damage and that I would be reconsidering my position in the affair in the light of our conversation.
6. I am passing a copy of this minute to the Foreign Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —That document was wilfully excluded from the report tabled by the Minister for Finance because it reflects very badly, I believe, on Mr Henderson and his First Assistant Secretary of the management division, Mr R. J. Smith. Senators and others are already aware of how the originator of that document, that is, Mr Witheford, with the help of a number of Department of Foreign Affairs staff, the unions and professional legal assistants, provided Mr Street with details of a series of financial irregularities in Tehran, London and Hong Kong in which a First Assistant Secretary, Mr Ivor Bowden, was I believe involved. The relevant statement dated 8 April from Mr Witheford, the head of the Philippines-Thailand-Burma section, to Mr Street has again been excluded from the report prepared by the Department of Finance. I tender it for inclusion in Hansard. It is signed by the author of the previous document and is addressed to the Minister himself. I seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: PARLIAMENTARY QUESTION FROM SENATOR PRIMMER TEHRAN: ALLEGED EMBEZZLEMENT
As requested by you on 23 March, I attach an outline of some financial irregularities (involving a particular senior officer) which occurred at Tehran and at related Locations.

2. I regret that it was not possible for me to get this material to you before your departure from Canberra on 25 March. There was a combination of reasons for this, including the need to contact a number of serving and retired colleagues, the need to search through considerable documentation and the need to obtain legal advice (explained below).

3. To the greatest possible extent I have indicated where relevant documentation can be sought. In this connection I wish to record that the Secretary has refused to make available to me any documents or files relating to this matter. I have, perforce, relied on my own memory and on those of numerous serving and retired colleagues, together with documents which had earlier been available to us in Tehran and Canberra.

4. It concerns me that there is no possibility of legal action being taken against me for having spoken out. For instance, on 11 March, 1981, the First Assistant Secretary, Management and Foreign Service Division, indicated to me that he would consider making my 'X' file available to others to enable them to take possible legal action against me. The senior officer referred to in paragraph 1 is referred to throughout as ''Jason''. Other officers are referred to by an alphabetical code which is being made available to you separately upon certain conditions.

5. I expect that I shall be able to pass on to you some further relevant information during the next few weeks. I am awaiting further details from some officers, both serving and retired. I am awaiting a response from Mr A. P. Renouf to whom I wrote on 1 April. (A copy of that letter is held in your office .) I expect that he will have useful information to offer, including, perhaps, a more detailed exposition of allegations of dishonesty which he recently made against a senior officer.

6. I am concerned that these matters may be lightly dismissed by senior officers. This would demonstrate the blatant disregard for the application of regulations etc. which has already been shown. For example, I have, since November, 1980, been seeking access to documents relevant to the whole question. In doing so I have been stalled and blocked by senior officers at every turn. These actions have been contrary to the requirement for appeals to be determined expeditiously. In my assessment reports for 1980 and 1981 my supervisor criticised me for spending too much time on these matters. I am fearful of further pressure on me and the other officers concerned. I request that you grant me an interview to enable me to discuss certain of the above matters with you.

TALK.START.PARA: —In incorporating this document in Hansard, I draw the attention of honourable senators in particular to paragraph 4 which, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It concerns me that there is a possibility of legal action being taken against me--
for having spoken out. For instance, on 11 March, 1981, the First Assistant Secretary, Management and Foreign Service Division-
indicated to me that he would consider making my 'x' file--
I would not have a clue what an 'x' file is, but I presume that it is an interdepartmental file-
available to others to enable them to take possible legal action against me.

As far as I can determine, no action whatsoever has yet been taken to examine that threat, which was obviously conveyed to frighten Mr Witheford into silence. In this connection, I inform honourable senators that both Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden have threatened to take legal action for defamation against me and a number of media organisations and, in fact, have taken out a writ against the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

Details of Mr Bowden's various activities, together with a large sheaf of accounting vouchers and other evidence, were attached to that submission. Subsequently Mr Henderson, in what was presumably intended as a show of innocence, let it be known that the Australian Federal Police would be invited to examine the report of the Department of Finance. However, at least a fortnight prior to the submission of the evidence to Mr Street, Mr Henderson had commenced to implement a bold and shameless cover-up plan. As a first step, he took action to deprive Mr Witheford and his workmates of the higher duties opportunities normally available in the Department. This entailed a loss of pay to the staff involved and has been repeated several times. The unions and the Public Service Board have been unable to prevent these crude acts of retribution . At the same time, there was an abortive attempt to shift Mr Witheford, without even an hour's notice, to a new location in the Department.

A few days later, on 31 March, Mr Henderson let it be known that a determined program of consultation and influence aimed at the Department of Finance's investigators had begun. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a note dated 31 March from Mr Henderson to that effect. That note is addressed to Mr Witheford and signed by Mr Henderson.

I refer to your minute of 30 March 1982, addressed to me. Your minute seriously misrepresents the situation. You have not been requested by the Minister to prepare a report as your minute asserts. You have been asked to pass to the Minister's Office any information which you hold concerning alleged financial irregularities in the Australian Embassy in Tehran so that that information can be thoroughly and promptly investigated by officers of the Department of Finance . You have no authority to carry out any investigation in this matter; any investigation will be carried out by appropriately qualified officers from the Department of Finance.

2. This matter has been further discussed with officers of the Department of Finance who have made it clear that they are most concerned that any information should be submitted for investigation promptly and that, in accordance with the request from the Minister's Office to you on 25 March, submission of that information should not be delayed awaiting the Minister's return. Officers of the Department of Finance consider that you have now had adequate time in which to consider your position and seek any necessary advice and have therefore requested that any information which you hold should be furnished without any further delay.

3. If you have knowledge of any matter which bears upon the allegation please convey it forthwith to the Minister's Office so that it may be fully and promptly investigated by the professionally qualified officers of the Department of Finance who are ready to commence any necessary investigation. Further delay can only hinder the prompt and just resolution of these allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that a sustained effort aimed at the Finance team continued during the months of the investigation. In early May, a number of staff members who had served with Mr Bowden in Tehran and other posts were interviewed. Later that month, before Mr Witheford and a retired senior officer, Mr R. E. Johns, had been interviewed about the allegations, a Press item appeared to the effect that Mr Bowden had been cleared by the Finance team. According to the Press, that leak was subsequently confirmed later that day by a Foreign Affairs spokesman. The conclusions in that leaked interim report seemed to be exactly the same as those contained in the final report before the Senate as of the week before last.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the conclusions of that report were written before the investigation commenced. Apart from the fact that its conclusions had become public before it had interviewed two of the main people involved, the Finance inquiry gave several Foreign Affairs officers reason for concern. This is outlined in the note by Mr Witheford which appears in the appendices to the Finance report. This points towards the following reasons for suspicion as to the bona fides of the Finance investigation: Firstly, several misleading draft records of interviews with witnesses prepared by Finance were heavily biased in Mr Bowden's favour; secondly, a total lack of work on the cover-up allegations; thirdly, the refusal by Foreign Affairs-that is, Mr Henderson-to give witnesses, Mr Witheford and Mr Henne in particular, access to relevant documentation; the apparent 'loss' by Foreign Affairs of important files, of a letter concerning the Tehran scandal received by Mr Renouf, the then departmental head, from Mr Witheford in 1975 and some of the Henderson-Bowden correspondence regarding Tehran; fourthly, the team's apparent lack of interest in pursuing obvious leads ; and, fifthly, occasional instances of hostility by one of the team members apparently designed to daunt interviewees.

Before considering each of the allegations against Mr Bowden in detail, I want to comment briefly on the involvement in this matter of the Australian Federal Police. There is no doubt-the police tapes of interviews with witnesses will help prove it-that the police sergeants conducting the investigation based on this hopelessly dishonest Finance report had been told to endorse that document. In doing so, they would seem to have been pressured from on high to adopt dirty tactics aimed at forcing Mr Witheford and even his wife to withdraw or modify evidence. As Mr Street said, this disturbing aspect of the affair is now in the hands of the Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, and the Australian Federal Police internal investigation group. We will doubtless be hearing more of that.

Having treated voluntary witnesses to Mr Bowden's activities in this illegal manner, the police reported back to Mr Henderson in terms which would no doubt have gratified him. Indeed, the advice of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) to Mr Street mirrored the misconduct of his police officers in that he stated that Mr Witheford possesses no evidence and implied, falsely I believe, that other witnesses had withdrawn evidence under Australian Federal Police questioning. We should remember that all the evidence available to Mr Witheford had been sent to Mr Street as long ago as early April and elaborated upon in subsequent interviews with the Department of Finance and the Australian Federal Police fraud squad.

Mr Newman's assertion that 'there is insufficient evidence to demonstrate that Mr Bowden acted in an improper manner, let alone criminally', leaves me speechless; but only for a moment. That the police believed it to be both appropriate and necessary to misbehave in the way that they did is clear evidence that the senior police and the Foreign Affairs staff handling the cover up had, for some reason, pressed the panic button. I am confident that this error of judgment will prove to be the undoing of those involved.

I do not have the time to respond to all Mr Street's points in detail. In any case, these could be dealt with more effectively in a less hurried way by perhaps the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, were this Parliament to deem it wise to put this matter before it. The relevant Estimates committees might also usefully raise some of these matters in their hearings. However, I think it is both necessary and appropriate for me to cover briefly the various known activities in which Mr Bowden engaged, if only to redress the obviously distorted way in which the Finance report purports to clear him. I exposed some of these malpractices in the Senate on 29 April and each of them appears to be well based. My estimate then of $10,000 to $15,000 being embezzled by Mr Bowden would now appear to have been pretty close to the mark. I shall now go into the specific areas where I originally made some allegations. Others were unknown to me at the time but have been brought to my attention since then.

The first allegation concerns the nanny's fare. Let me make it abundantly clear that Mr Bowden intentionally arranged matters so that the High Commission in London paid the full bill for his nanny's fare. The amount he almost got away with was substantial, equal to several months' livelihood for an unemployed man or woman. Anyone with the time to do so should look at the Finance report, particularly at Mr Johns's notes written at that time, and at the obvious reluctance to take disciplinary action on the part of several very senior people , including the man who told the Department of Finance that he did not now recall the incident. No amount of red herrings can obscure the fact that Mr Bowden was caught redhanded and admitted his guilt by repaying the large sum involved. As the then head of the Finance Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs wrote on 26 September 1960:
I now query whether there has been a like transaction previously.

Leaving aside the Hong Kong irregularity, I now wish to cover the various irregularities or embezzlements-call them what you will-in Tehran. I think it must be clearly understood that Canberra was well aware that there were problems in the Tehran Embassy. Having visited Tehran on a parliamentary delegation in 1973, I am very much aware of the problems which existed at that time in the Tehran Embassy. As a result of formal complaints from the Department of Trade and Resources and informal expressions of concern to Canberra friends by several staff at the Embassy, it was decided to conduct a post-liaison visit in late 1975 to see what was wrong and to fix it up. Who turned out to be the visiting inspector? It was none other than Mr Henderson, the head of the Management and Foreign Service Division, who made only a slight pretence of evenhandedness. He stayed with Mr Bowden throughout the visit and conducted interviews with all Embassy staff, most of whom were courageous enough-or was it foolhardy-to speak frankly to him. Thereafter he conducted frequent private correspondence with Mr Bowden and, at the request of the latter, terminated the postings of the second in command, Mr Witheford, and the Senior Administrative Officer, Mr Henne, both of whom had clashed with Mr Bowden on official and other questions. At that time the Administrative Attache, Mr F. F. Sergi, after a serious clash with Mr Bowden , asked Mr Henderson to bring him home also. However, since Mr Henderson doubted even his expert ability to keep the lid on things if a third man were to be brought back to Canberra, he denied Mr Sergi's request. From 1975 onwards to this very hour, Mr Henderson and a few of his colleagues have worked tirelessly to prevent Mr Bowden's exposure. He would never have been exposed if I had not raised the matter in Parliament.

I turn briefly to the various techniques which Mr Bowden employed. I refer to the payment of children. All staff in the Embassy were entitled to gardening and snow clearing services at Embassy expense. Mr Bowden employed free of charge a large retinue of obviously underemployed servants, including not one, but two gardeners. The Embassy was thus providing more than adequately for any snow clearing that was required. It should be pointed out here that any person who thinks that they can garden in Tehran in the middle of winter should think again . Obviously the gardeners would be underemployed in that capacity during the middle of winter when the place is covered with snow. Nevertheless, Mr Bowden forced Embassy staff to pay him, winter after winter, for money he claimed he had paid to his sons for snow clearing. The first officer to actually refuse to pay Mr Bowden was the Senior Administrative Officer, Mr Henne, who had been ordered back to Canberra by Mr Henderson. Contrary to the misleading assertions in the report from the Department of Finance, Mr Sergi also then refused to sign a snow clearing voucher as the officer incurring the expense. Mr Bowden immediately relieved Mr Sergi of his financial delegation, replacing him with a more flexible officer who paid those and all future snow clearing claims. The evidence for the assertions in my last two sentences is contained in a letter to the Australian Federal Police dated 16 August 1982. I seek the permission of the Senate to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

In the course of my conversation with you and Mr Wallace on 13 August I expressed concern that the Finance Report on the Tehran embezzlement allegations had not included some key documents originated by me. (I had already provided you with a copy of my submission of 8 April 1982 to Minister Street.) I now attach copies of my minute of 22 March 1982 to Mr R. J. Smith (copied to Minister Street) and my letter of 9 July 1982 to Mr M. Woolley (with attachment) concerning serious errors in the Department of Finance's handling of this matter .

My wife and I are most concerned at certain aspects of the separate interviews you conducted with us on 13 August. The only one I raise in this letter is the allegations made by you and Mr Wallace that Messrs. Johns, Henne and F. Sergi, under your questioning, had withdrawn or amended certain of their previous statements (both written and oral) concerning the Tehran and related irregularities. With respect, I do not accept what my wife and I were told in this regard and wish to draw some related allegations to your attention.

(i) I attach a copy of a letter dated 24 October 1982 to the Chairman, Promotions Appeal Committee. This letter was prepared in consultation with Mr Henne and at his request and a copy is held by ACOA. You will note that it covers the question of corruption involving Australia-based staff at the Embassy .

(ii) In the Finance Report there is a denial of my allegation that Mr Sergi was relieved of his financial delegation following a clash over a snowclearing payment. I confirm my recollection and have turned up two relevant letters from Mr Sergi. In his letter of 22 February 1976 to me he advised: ''I am no longer officer incurring expense, Harris is both O.I.E. and C.O., i.e. only his signature appears on the voucher.'' In his letter of 23 March 1976 to Mr Henne ( which he asked be shown to me) Mr Sergi stated in part: ''They've fixed it that Harris is both officer incurring expense and certifying officer so I don't have anything to do with accounts in effect. The boss is still claiming snowclearing for his kid and Harris has paid them all.''
I expect to be in touch with you again very shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has also been alleged that Mr Bowden would obtain money for snow clearing after very light snow falls. Here again, the amount of money embezzled would be enough to cover the living costs of an unemployed Australian for a couple of months. I now deal with the purchase of air tickets. Mr Bowden was a senior officer in the relevant branch of the Public Service Board in 1968 when these income test arrangements were introduced. What I am saying in effect is that Mr Bowden would know the regulation backwards. Accordingly his failure to declare the very substantial incomes of his children was obviously intentional and aimed at getting free air tickets from the taxpayers for his family. We are told by the Department of Finance that the Department of Foreign Affairs-meaning Mr Henderson-can find no evidence that Mr Bowden actually told the Department that his children had no income. Perhaps there are many more files missing than we realised. Again, the red herring in the report of the Department of Finance must be stripped away and Mr Bowden presented with a bill for the thousands of dollars dishonestly spent on these air fares. The Department of Finance, apparently deliberately, is very coy about the income of these children, but it is obvious that they are very wealthy young people. We must insist that all the lurid details of their incomes, including their 'snow job' incomes, be tabled in full. It may well be that tax has been evaded on this Tehran money.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to wages paid to servants, this is the only irregularity where apparently genuine new evidence in Mr Bowden's favour has been put forward. The witness concerned is an officer very close to Mr Henderson. I think we need an explanation as to why there is no record of interview with that man and also as to where all the documents kept in a metal box are filed. This is a matter which the Public Accounts Committee could investigate for us.

I deal with the misuse of cars. I think it is now generally accepted that the misuse of cars did occur, in particular with a guest of Mr Bowden's-by one account, his cousin-for weeks on end. Mr Bowden's statement in appendix 20 of the Finance report that none of his visitors had been authorised to use an official vehicle for as much as a day, let alone for weeks, is, I believe, a barefaced lie. But then a very senior man who had served with Mr Bowden at another post recently stated, with some heat, that he would be happy to pay his own fare to Canberra to tell Mr Street that Mr Bowden is a professional liar. Large chauffered Mercedes do not come cheaply. The actual costs incurred must once again be left to the Public Accounts Committee or perhaps to the relevant Senate Estimates committee. Contrary to the misleading Finance assertion, Sir William McMahon did complain to Mr Bowden who reported the matter to Canberra- presumably to Mr Henderson. Presumably, there is another missing file.

In relation to the representation allowance, according to the Department of Finance Mr Bowden may have been unduly secretive about his representation allowance files. It is clear to me that this was because he was padding the expenditure reports which he sent to Canberra where they were processed without a murmur by subordinates of Mr Henderson. According to Appendix cc of the Finance report, he obviously claimed falsely for the costs of extra servants who were a figment of his imagination. Neither the former technique nor the allegation concerning excessive claims for liquor costs have been examined by the Department of Finance, perhaps because they were too hard. Again, that is another matter for possible action by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. If that is the case that Committee must be given full access to all files and witnesses. According to my information Mr Bowden could well have received roughly $20,000 tax free for representation, so the amount falsely vouched could be fairly large.

In relation to further irregularities, I suggest that the Senate address itself to Appendix ee of the Finance report which provides clear evidence about these irregularities. However, the report seeks to obscure the fact that Mr Bowden wilfully submitted false Treasury regulation 132 certificates in order to keep Canberra in the dark about the state of the Embassy's finances. Attempts to justify Mr Bowden's acts by affirming that some other ambassadors were also dishonest in this way, or by trying to blame other officers at the Embassy, should be dismissed, in my view, as unworthy of credence. Mr Bowden routinely submitted false certificates, which is a serious offence, involving a possible gaol sentence under the Crimes Act.

I now come to the fraudulent conversion of a cheque in Hong Kong. This action resulted in the loss of $8,734.99 of taxpayers' money in 1972-73. While there is a mass of documentation provided about this irregularity, one gains the impression that the Hong Kong and Australian police investigators did not treat the Australian staff of the Australian Commission as potential suspects. Furthermore, the Department of Finance records a number of interviewees as being strongly of the view that Mr Bowden could not have been responsible for the fraud. But why take up the Senate's valuable time in discussing this matter since Mr Street told us in his statement:
The fraudulent conversion occurred before Mr Bowden's arrival at the post.

In other words the Minister for Foreign Affairs provides an alibi for his 'loyal and dedicated public servant, who has served successive governments with great distinction for over 30 years'. Mr Street provides Mr Bowden with an alibi; therefore he could not have been involved in defrauding the people of Australia of over $8,700. That alibi is totally false.

This Government has yet again been caught out purveying lies to the Parliament. Let me explain: According to documents tabled by the Minister for Finance that cheque was drawn in Hong Kong on 20 October 1972 and fraudulently converted shortly thereafter. According to Mr Street's Department's statement of service Mr Bowden arrived in Hong Kong on 10 May 1972, if one believes page 25 of the report, or on 6 June 1972 if one prefers to believe page 129. I never cease to be amazed by the elasticity of facts in the Department of Foreign Affairs. According to page 163 of that statement, Mr Curtis was appointed to fill Mr Bowden's position in Canberra on 1 July 1972. Therefore, according to the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Bowden assumed charge of the Australian High Commission in Hong Kong at least four months and two weeks before that cheque for $8,734.99 was drawn.

Why would Mr Street have us believe otherwise? Before the trail gets any colder there must be a thorough on-the-spot investigation of this fraud, not by Mr Henderson but by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts with appropriate police assistance. I have in mind proposing that either the Victorian or New South Wales police be invited to participate in this inquiry. (Extension of time granted). In my view both Mr Street and the Minister for Finance stand convicted of having wilfully misled Parliament after six months of investigation of these frauds. The proper course for them to take is clear. Although honourable senators are only too well aware that the threshold of ministerial responsibility accepted by this Government is now lower than the proverbial snake's belly, as I urged four months ago Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden must be suspended immediately, if only to prevent them from designing, engineering and implementing yet another cover-up operation. There must be no more missing files , pressured witnesses and ostracism of honest officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs. The careers of these men who have been harmed by the cover-up of the Tehran affair for the past seven years must be restored without delay.

In the report the Minister for Foreign Affairs put down the week before last he stated that I-Senator Primmer-must now ask myself a serious question: Have my actions been consistent with the standards expected of a member of this Parliament? I demand that those members of the Government implicated in this affair put that question to themselves. I think any honourable senator will agree that for sure Mr Street has been hoisted on his own petard.

This has not been an easy matter to bring forward. I believed at the time that I was on to something that was being hidden. I believed honest officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs were being stymied and repressed and having all sorts of malicious rumours spread about them. I believe that many people in Canberra are of the opinion that some of these honest officers are now mentally upset, disturbed and what not. But I have it on good authority from other people who have known them for years that there is nothing wrong with their mental capacity whatsoever. This is part of a giant smear campaign by people at the top to cover up for their buddies, mates and friends at the expense of honest people . I believe I would have been remiss in my duty as a citizen and as a senator of this place, representing the great bulk of the electors in Victoria-as it turned out after the last election-were I not to air this matter as I have done today. I think the ball is back in the court of the Department, the Government and particularly Mr Street.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been in the Senate chamber to hear the bulk of the very detailed comments made by Senator Primmer with respect to the inquiry which was made by the Department of Foreign Affairs and by other departments into allegations he raised in this place some time ago. Unfortunately I am not fully briefed on this matter, indeed I am not briefed at all, and I am in no position to respond in detail to the points he has made. I regret that because, of course, the issues he has raised are serious. They have already received a great deal of attention and time not only in the Parliament but also by way of investigation. They have been the subject of a statement and Senator Primmer has now, of course, challenged a number of the elements of the statement which has been put down. I can do no more than refer the transcript of what has been said by Senator Primmer to Mr Street. I will do that as soon as that transcript is available.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a Japanese company purchased, and sub-divided, a 328 hectare grazing property near Gympie, Queensland, for sale to Japanese citizens; if so, why?
(2) Is this quality grazing land to be sub-divided and sold to wealthy Japanese for the purpose of displaying a picture and a wall plaque of their 'ranch in Australia'.
(3) Is this property one of about 45 such Japanese-owned parcels of land in the Barambah electorate of the Queensland Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen.

(4) Are there any controls to prevent land in Australia being sub-divided for sale overseas; if not, will legislation be introduced in the autumn session of Parliament, 1982, to implement strict controls over the sale of freehold land to foreign investors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) A Japanese owned company did purchase such a grazing property near Gympie, Queensland, in early 1980. The company, which already owned two other rural properties near Gympie, sought and obtained foreign investment approval for this transaction on a retrospective basis. The transaction involved a consideration of $81,000 and the land was purchased for development as a cattle raising enterprise in conjunction with the company's other two properties which were purchased previously. Cattle raised on the properties are owned by members of a Japanese club associated with the company.

The company subsequently sought approval to sub-divide the last acquired property for resale to members of the Japanese club. However, this proposal was rejected by the Government on the basis that it would not be consistent with the Government's foreign investment policy. The Japanese company involved has since advised my Department that, in view of the Government's decision, it does not intend to sell any portions of the land to Japanese or other interests.

(3) I am advised that since the Foreign Investment Review Board was established in April 1976, only 3 proposals by Japanese to acquire land in the Barambah electorate have been approved under foreign investment policy. The proposals are those referred to in response to questions (1) and (2). There may have been other small acquisitions of rural land in the area which have not been submitted to the Government for approval, possibly because either they have not fallen within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act or have been exempt from examination under foreign investment policy where they involved a consideration below the $350,000 threshold. (see also answer to (4) below).

(4) Proposals by foreign interests to acquire rural properties which constitute businesses fall within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act and require approval under the Government's foreign investment policy.

Under its policy, the Government is concerned to ensure that foreign interests do not engage in property acquisitions of a speculative nature or intended purely for capital gain or investment income, without accompanying benefits to the Australian economy. Accordingly, proposals involving the purchase of rural land simply with a view to sub-division and sale to foreign interests are not likely to meet the policy guidelines. Moreover, in its consideration of foreign investment proposals, the Government seeks to ensure that rural properties have been advertised or otherwise offered for sale in a way normal for the industry and that interested Australian purchasers have been given an opportunity to bid for them.

On 20 January 1982, following a review of the Government's foreign investment policy, I announced that a more restrictive approach would be adopted towards foreign acquisitions of rural properties, primarily by way of strengthening the test of benefits from a proposal before approval is given. Under this approach, subject to possible interested Australian purchasers having been given appropriate opportunities to bid, foreign investment approval is normally restricted to the following types of proposals: those where the purchasers have firm plans to establish residence in Australia; those which offer significant economic benefits; and, where the economic benefits are small, those where there is an effective partnership (usually a 50/50 partnership) between Australian investors and the foreign investors in the ownership and control of the property . Particular attention is paid to the advice of the State or Territory concerned in determining whether or not a proposed acquisition would lead to significant economic benefits.

In the context of its foreign investment policy review, the Government recognised that, although acquisitions of farms are normally subject to examination by the Foreign Investment Review Board, irrespective of value, it is possible that some foreign interests may be acquiring small rural holdings which are no longer operational farms and which are exempt from examination under the Foreign Takeovers Act or foreign investment policy. However, the Government does not believe that it would be feasible for it to monitor such minor land acquisitions. Further, the capacity of such investors to make significant capital gains may be dependent upon the land being approved for sub-division or re-zoned for urban purposes. As this matter relates essentially to questions of land usage and as the Commonwealth does not have the capacity to deal effectively with it, it has been drawn to the attention of the States.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the concern felt by the North Queensland fishing and prawning industries over the likelihood of Japanese and Papua New Guinea (PNG) fishing companies setting up a joint fishing industry in the Torres Strait following ratification of the PNG/Australia Border Agreement, which, in effect, would enable Japanese fishermen operating PNG vessels to fish well inside Australian territorial waters.

(2) Can the Minister for Primary Industry give an assurance that if PNG vessels are allowed to fish in Australian waters, then no other foreign interests will be able to take advantage of this dispensation to the PNG fishing industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the concern of north Queensland fishermen over the implementation of the Torres Strait Treaty.

Under Article 27 of the Torres Strait Treaty, provision is made for Australia and PNG to consult concerning any proposed exploitation of protected zone commercial fisheries which includes third country participation.

Furthermore, vessels under the control of nationals of a third country will not be permitted to exploit protected zone commercial fisheries without the concurrence of the responsible authorities in Australia and PNG.

(2) The Commonwealth consults with the Australian fishing industry on all proposals involving foreign fishing interests. Should PNG seek access under the terms of the Treaty to waters under Australian jurisdiction, by vessels with third country registration, crew or equity ownership, the views expressed by the Australian industry would be taken into account.

I should point out however that opportunities will exist for Australian companies to join with PNG in exploiting the shared resources of the protected zone and resources outside the zone which will come under PNG jurisdiction.
